input: Hello doctor,I had mumps five months ago and after that, I started to have an infection in my left testes. It was swollen and now it has shrunk to almost half the size of the other one. As I am sexually active, I feel a pain in each of the vas deferens after sex. If I do not have sex for days, they become sensitive. I was treated with Ceftum 500 mg, the first time I had an infection. Now my question is, is there any chance that the infection is still in my body? And, do I need to get examined for it? For the time being, please suggest some precautionary antibiotics for my relief.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:

As I am sexually active, I feel a pain in each of the vas deferens after sex. If I do not have sex for days, they become sensitive. I was treated with Ceftum 500 mg, the first time I had an infection. Now my question is, is there any chance that the infection is still in my body? And, do I need to get examined for it? For the time being, please suggest some precautionary antibiotics for my relief.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you still have an infection in your testicles. The swelling and pain you experienced could be indicative of an inflammatory condition such as epididymitis or orchitis.

To determine if there is an infection present, I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a urologist. They will be able to perform a physical examination and possibly order further tests such as a urine or blood test to check for signs of infection.

In the meantime, it would be advisable to avoid sexual activity until you have been diagnosed and treated. This will help alleviate the discomfort and reduce the risk of complications.

As for precautionary antibiotics, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific situation. Depending on the cause and severity of your symptoms, they may prescribe a course of antibiotics to help manage the infection and provide relief.

Please consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment options.

input: Hello doctor,I am trying to conceive but my husband and I did cocaine a week ago. How long should my husband and I wait to safely continue to try to get pregnant? How long until it is out of our system? How long does cocaine stay in sperm? Thanks in advance.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am trying to conceive but my husband and I did cocaine a week ago. How long should my husband and I wait to safely continue to try to get pregnant? How long until it is out of our system? How long does cocaine stay in sperm? Thanks in advance.

### Response:As a doctor, I would advise you and your husband to seek immediate medical attention. Using cocaine can have serious health consequences, especially when trying to conceive. Cocaine use can lead to fertility problems, miscarriage, and other complications during pregnancy.

The time it takes for cocaine to completely leave your system depends on various factors such as frequency of use, metabolism, and overall health. On average, it takes about 7-10 days for cocaine to be eliminated from the body. However, it can persist in the sperm for up to 48 hours after the last use.

Given the potential risks to both your health and the development of a healthy pregnancy, it is important to avoid trying to conceive for at least 18 weeks after the last time you used cocaine. This will allow enough time for the drug to completely leave your system and reduce the potential harm to your future baby.

I strongly recommend seeking counseling and support from a healthcare professional who can provide guidance and resources to help you with your journey towards conception.

input: Hello doctor,I am currently on the Yaz contraceptive pill. I skipped my sugar pills for around four months and had a breakthrough period this month. Nothing hurts or is sore, I just want to know how long I am going to have the brown discharge and if I should be worried or if I should do anything about it?

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it is not uncommon for a woman to experience a brown discharge after stopping hormonal contraceptives such as the Yaz pill. This type of discharge usually resolves on its own within a few weeks or months.

In your case, since you had a breakthrough period and still have some residual brown discharge, it is likely that your body is adjusting to the absence of hormonal contraception. The duration of the brown discharge can vary from person to person, but it usually subsides within a few weeks to months.

However, if the brown discharge is accompanied by other concerning symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, fever, or significant vaginal bleeding, you should consult with your healthcare provider for further evaluation.

In the meantime, you can try using a panty liner to protect your clothing during the brown discharge period. It is important to maintain good hygiene by washing your underwear regularly and avoiding douching.

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it appears that your son has a significant difference in his eye prescriptions. This condition is known as anisometropia.

To address this issue, here are some precautions you can take:

1. Ensure proper lighting: Make sure the lighting in the room is adequate and evenly distributed. This can help reduce eye strain and discomfort caused by unequal light exposure.

2. Encourage regular eye examinations: It is important for your son to have regular eye exams to monitor his vision and ensure that any changes are detected early.

3. Provide appropriate glasses or contact lenses: Depending on the severity of the difference in prescriptions, your son may require glasses or contact lenses to correct his vision. These will help compensate for the difference in refractive errors between his eyes.

4. Limit screen time: Excessive time spent on digital screens can strain the eyes and exacerbate symptoms of eye fatigue. Encourage your son to take regular breaks from screens and engage in activities that promote good eye health, such as outdoor recreation or reading books.

5. Promote good posture: Poor posture can contribute to eye strain and discomfort. Encourage your son to maintain a proper posture while sitting,

1. Hormonal imbalance: Sex can disrupt the natural hormonal balance in the body, which may temporarily delay or alter the menstrual cycle.

3. Stress or emotional changes: Emotional stress, significant life events, or changes in stress levels can affect hormone levels and menstruation.

input: Hello doctor,Some mornings during the week I get a quick flash of numbness over my left temple. It is never at night or during the day. It can happen more than once sometimes. If I move, roll over, or get up, I can make it stop. It does not hurt and is very fast. What does this sound like?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,Some mornings during the week I get a quick flash of numbness over my left temple. It is never at night or during the day. It can happen more than once sometimes. If I move, roll over, or get up, I can make it stop. It does not hurt and is very fast. What does this sound like?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, the symptoms of quick flashes of numbness over the left temple that occur only during the week mornings and can be stopped by moving, rolling over, or getting up, sound like a condition called parasomnia. Parasomnia refers to unusual sleep-related experiences that can happen between wakefulness and sleep. In this case, the patient is experiencing a phenomenon known as a sleep paralyze episode.

Sleep paralysis is a temporary condition where the muscles are temporarily unable to move, usually occurring just as a person wakes up or falls asleep. It can cause a feeling of being unable to speak or move, accompanied by vivid sensations such as pressure or weight on the chest or a feeling of being watched. In some cases, individuals may also experience hallucinations or a sense of terror during these episodes.

It is important for the patient to discuss these symptoms with a healthcare professional to rule out any underlying medical conditions and to receive proper evaluation and management.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old female who has had an elevated ferritin level for many years now. My last ferritin level was 342, 20 days back. My ferritin level has been as high as 390. My TIBC, UIBC, iron, and iron saturation have always been within normal range. My glucose has always ranged from 100 to 104. I was tested for hemochromatosis and results are negative. My doctors keep telling me that we will just watch my ferritin level and I have bloodwork done every six months. I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia last year. I am looking for some answers and some help.

Nonetheless, regular monitoring of your ferritin levels and periodic reevaluation by your doctor would be prudent.

Since your TIBC (total iron-binding capacity), UIBC (unbound iron-binding capacity), iron, and iron saturation levels have always been within normal range, this suggests that your body's iron metabolism is functioning normally.

Considering your symptoms of fibromyalgia, it is important to discuss this with your doctor as well

input: Hello doctor,I have had a fishy odor down there since I was in elementary school. I was not sexually active at all either. Just a couple years ago I realized I might have something called bacterial vaginosis. I went to the doctor for it a couple years ago and got prescribed Metronidazole and it did nothing for me. Ever since then I have not really gone to the doctor about it again. I am worried because I have read that BV left untreated can make you infertile. How common is it that this could happen? And do you have any tips for me?

And do you have any tips for me?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is concerning that you have experienced a fishy odor since childhood and were recently diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina. It is important to seek medical attention and properly treat BV to prevent complications such as infertility.

The likelihood of BV causing infertility is low, but it can be a potential complication if left untreated. However, with appropriate treatment, the chances of restoring fertility are good.

Here are some tips for managing BV:

1. Consult a healthcare professional: Schedule an appointment with your doctor or gynecologist to discuss your symptoms and receive an accurate diagnosis.

2. Take the prescribed medication: If prescribed Metronidazole, complete the full course of treatment even if you did not experience relief the first time. Your doctor may prescribe different antibiotics depending on the severity of your infection.

3. Practice good hygiene: Maintain good personal hygiene by washing the outside of your vagina with mild soap and water. Avoid using harsh soaps, douches, or vaginal deodorants as they can disrupt the natural balance

input: Hello doctor,My body is getting severe itching after taking a bath or while sweating. Initially, it used to happen only in winter 4 to 5 years back and then gradually started in rainy days also. Now in summer also while sweating. It is so irritating like that I am going to be mad. I have stopped using soap and also took Clonafit 0.25 mg and Betonix- 10 prescribed by a dermatologist but there is no improvement. Please help me out of this.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My body is getting severe itching after taking a bath or while sweating. Initially, it used to happen only in winter 4 to 5 years back and then gradually started in rainy days also. Now in summer also while sweating. It is so irritating like that I am going to be mad. I have stopped using soap and also took Clonafit 0.25 mg and Betonix- 10 prescribed by a dermatologist but there is no improvement. Please help me out of this.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you may be experiencing symptoms of scabies. Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by microscopic mites called Sarcoptes scabiei.

The itching you described is a common symptom of scabies, especially during bathing or when sweating. The mites burrow into the skin and lay eggs, which can lead to intense itching and irritation.

I would recommend visiting a dermatologist for a proper diagnosis. They may perform a physical examination and possibly a skin scraping test to confirm the presence of scabies mites. Treatment for scabies usually involves prescription medications such as topical creams or lotions that contain permethrin or ivermectin.

In addition to medical treatment, it is important to take proper hygiene measures to prevent the spread of scabies. This includes washing clothes, bedding, and towels in hot water, and avoiding close contact with individuals who have scabies until you have completed your treatment and are no longer contagious.

Please consult with a dermatologist for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 25-year-old male. I do not have any medical history. Been always healthy. For the past 3 months, I have been experiencing this facial tightness which comes pretty often throughout the day with different intensity. The facial tension usually comes half an hour after I leave the bed. The tightness on my face happens to be on both sides of my face but usually more intense on the right. At times, I can feel it from my neck all the way up to my face. As of recent, I have been feeling this slight burning sensation on my chest to my shoulders as well. Prior to this facial tightness, I have been suffering from this burning feeling on the centre of my chest for about a month. It was my first time experiencing heartburn and I thought it was heart related. Went for X-rays and echo heart ultrasound. Everything came out fine. I have a healthy heart. What made the burning chest sensation go away temporarily is lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol. And the weird part is the same thing helps me relieve my facial tightness temporarily is the same thing as that for the burning chest sensation; lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol.Since having this facial tightness, I have paid numerous visits to different doctors, even the neuro-specialist and they all said it was anxiety. The doctors did facial senses test where they take a piece of fine cotton to touch different parts of my face. I had to close my eyes and tell them where the spot is. I have no troubles at all. I did blood test. It came out normal. They told me I do not need to do any scans and that it was merely anxiety and it will go off by itself. I convinced myself that I had anxiety because of the one month heartburn ordeal that I was suffering from. Even though the facial tightness was there, I tried my utmost best to ignore it. I do not think that I have any anxiety in me now as I try not to think of the weird tightness sensation. However, it has been 3 whole months and now I am getting alarmed and worried that it is still here and with newer sensations as I described above. In all honesty, I do feel that the intensity of the facial tension as compared to I first experienced it, is less. However, it is always there even as when I am typing this. I do not see any physical change on my body. Not sure if it is neuro damage. I am worried sick.Hope I can get some form of advice and diagnosis.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,My mother is 75 years old. She had been treated for TB (tuberculosis) of the abdomen as her ultrasound of abdomen finding was thicken bowel loop. In general terms, it was informed about TB in her abdomen. Accordingly, medicines were given to her as per the advise of a local MD doctor. Treatment continued for three months and due to some discontinuation of medicine it relapsed and again she was diagnosed with Thicken bowel loop as per USG. Again treatment continued.However, while undergoing treatment she lost sensation in her legs and complained of losing sensation in her legs and numbness in her feet and was unable to put on slippers in her feet with difficulty in moving. She also complained that while moving she felt as if she was moving on a bed of soft cotton.Subsequent treatment by neuro experts revealed that overdose of treatment of her TB in abdomen resulted in this condition and she was diagnosed for peripheral neuropathy and was advised for biopsy for proper diagnosis. Meanwhile, she fell and hurt herself which was later on diagnosed that her spine at L3 - L4 was compressed due to felling abruptly and accordingly she was advised to take bed rest for three months. Slowly, she recovered from this condition felt pain in her back and was facing another kind of problem as she could not sit for a longer time and preferred to lay down on the bed.Finding her bad condition subsequetly, we also took consultation from other neuro experts at a prestigious institution where she was prescribed Lupivitin one tablet and Sammy one tablet.When condition persisted thereafter she was given Primosa one tablet daily, Neurox one tablet daily, Maxglobin 50 mg one tablet and Defart 6 mg.But, whenever she was given medicine her condition further aggravated. After about six months of treatment by the neuro expert, she has now been referred to the department of immunology for their advice. Meanwhile, we also took advice from a rheumatologist who diagnosed a kind of arthritis and started treating accordingly. He also started the course of Defzacort (steroid) along with other medicines. The steroid was prescribed with a decreasing dose per week from 60 mg per day to 6 mg per day.However, after taking about two months of steroid course her condition deteriorated and had severe breathlessness. Her blood sugar level also shot up and ultimately she was hospitalized and the treatment of steroid withdrawn. After 15 days of treatment at the hospital she recovered to her previous condition. But, her neuro problem of numbness in her legs and loss of sensation in legs still continues. Please help.

Intraarticular fractures are complex fractures that require specialized treatment to achieve optimal healing and minimize complications. Open Reduction Internal Fixation (ORIF) is a common surgical procedure used to treat these types of fractures. ORIF involves realigning the bone fragments and using screws, plates, or rods to hold them in place during the healing process.

Given the significant ulnar displacement seen on the X-ray, it is important to correct this as part of the treatment plan to prevent any functional impairment or deformity. Delaying treatment could lead to further displacement and potentially affect your hand function in the long term.

I would recommend reaching out to a specialist orthopedic surgeon who specializes in hand and wrist injuries. They will be able to assess your specific case, review the imaging studies, and determine the best course of action. This only briefly eases when I really do some throat opening exercises. I cannot talk for very long without everything getting sore still. I have been like this since the beginning of the year since I had a chest infection and pneumonia. My mouth is now getting sore from all the Gaviscon tablets as the liquid irritates the corners of my throat. I really do not know what else I can do. Therefore, in this case, it is unlikely that a TSH level of 18.64 indicates any significant problem or abnormality. However, it is important to consider the patient's overall health and medical history when interpreting any laboratory results. 5. Skin irritation: Friction, sweating, or rubbing against the skin can irritate the area and lead to pimples.

To determine the exact cause of your redness, it is important to consult with an eye care professional. They will be able to examine your eyes, evaluate your contact lens history, and provide appropriate advice and treatment options.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you are experiencing a condition called gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). GERD occurs when stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing irritation and discomfort. The pain around the belly button, warmth, itching, and taste sensations in the mouth are all common symptoms of GERD.

To confirm this diagnosis, I would recommend visiting a healthcare professional who can perform further evaluation. They may ask you questions about your medical history, conduct an examination, and possibly order additional tests such as an endoscopy or pH testing.

In the meantime, there are some lifestyle changes you can make to help alleviate your symptoms. These include avoiding trigger foods (such as spicy or fatty foods), eating smaller meals, avoiding lying down immediately after eating, and elevating the head of your bed.

It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,I have an odd thing happening in my left eye. I see a flash of light when I look right to left in the left side of my eye. It is a curve from top to bottom. It happens in daylight, nighttime, and even in the dark with my eyes closed. I move my pupil left to right and see a bright arc of light. I cannot make it stay there, it just flashes as I move my eye balls left to right. Any ideas?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have an odd thing happening in my left eye. I see a flash of light when I look right to left in the left side of my eye. It is a curve from top to bottom. It happens in daylight, nighttime, and even in the dark with my eyes closed. I move my pupil left to right and see a bright arc of light. I cannot make it stay there, it just flashes as I move my eye balls left to right. Any ideas?

### Response:Based on your description, you are experiencing a phenomenon called an "optical illusion" or "phosphene." It is caused by the movement of your eyes and not related to any eye condition or damage.

When you move your eyes from right to left, the outer edge of your right eye moves away from the object you are looking at while the inner part of your eye stays in focus. This creates a blind spot in your visual field for a brief moment. To compensate for this, your brain fills in that missing information by creating a flash of light or "phosphene" in the corresponding area of your left eye.

This optical illusion occurs because the part of your brain responsible for processing visual information is interconnected with the parts responsible for controlling eye movements. The flash of light you see is simply a result of this communication between your eyes and brain.

While it may be distracting or confusing at times, there is usually no cause for concern with this phenomenon. However, if you are experiencing any other symptoms such as pain, double vision, or significant visual impairment, it would be best to consult with an eye care professional to rule out any underlying eye conditions.

### Response:There are several possible causes for black spots on the tongue. One common cause is a condition called melanoma, which is a type of skin cancer that can occur on the tongue. However, melanoma is relatively rare and is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as pain or bleeding.

More commonly, black spots on the tongue can be caused by a condition called melanosis, which is the accumulation of pigmented cells on the tongue's surface. This can occur due to various factors such as genetics, exposure to certain chemicals, or irritation from oral habits like biting or picking at the tongue.

Other possible causes of black spots on the tongue include fungal infections, such as oral thrush, which cause white or grayish patches that may later develop black edges. Additionally, certain medications like iron supplements or antibiotics can cause a side effect of black discoloration on the tongue.

It is important to note that the exact cause of black spots on the tongue cannot always be determined without a thorough examination by a healthcare professional. If you notice any changes in your tongue, it is recommended to consult with a doctor or dentist for further evaluation and diagnosis.

### Response:Umbilical hernias are common and can often be treated with either open surgery or laparoscopy. The choice between the two depends on various factors such as the size of the hernia, the presence of any other medical conditions, and your surgeon's preference.

Open surgery, also known as an open reduction, involves making a small incision in the skin over the hernia site and using sutures or surgical mesh to repair the weakened muscle or tissue that is causing the hernia. This is a more traditional approach and may be recommended if there are complications or if the hernia is particularly large.

Laparoscopy, on the other hand, is a minimally invasive procedure that uses smaller incisions and a camera called a laparoscope to visualize and repair the hernia. It is often preferred for smaller hernias or when multiple hernias need to be repaired. This method usually results in less pain, shorter recovery time, and smaller scars.

After either surgery, it is important to allow enough time for healing before resuming heavy lifting or strenuous activities. It is best to consult with your surgeon who can provide specific guidance based on your

The contraceptive pill is highly effective in preventing pregnancy when taken consistently and correctly. It works by inhibiting ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus to prevent sperm from reaching the egg.

There are several types of contraceptive pills available, including combination pills (which contain estrogen and progestin) and progestin-only pills. Combination pills are more effective than progestin-only pills, but both types are highly effective when used correctly.

It's important to note that any medication, including contraceptive pills, may have potential side effects. However, most women tolerate these pills well and do not experience significant side effects. The most common side effects include nausea, breast tenderness, and changes in menstrual bleeding patterns.

To ensure the best possible results, it is advisable for you to consult with a healthcare professional who can assess your individual needs and recommend the most suitable contraceptive pill for you and your partner. They will provide detailed information about the different options available and help you make an informed decision.

input: Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?

### Response:HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) is a genetic condition that affects the macula, which is the part of the eye responsible for central vision. It is caused by mutations in certain genes.

The impact of HMD on a person can vary depending on the specific gene mutation and the stage at which it is diagnosed. In some cases, individuals may experience a gradual loss of central vision, leading to blurred or distorted vision. This can affect activities such as reading, driving, or recognizing faces.

While HMD does not typically cause complete blindness, it can significantly impact a person's quality of life by affecting their ability to see fine details clearly. In advanced stages, individuals may have difficulty with tasks that require sharp vision, such as reading or working on a computer.

However, it is important to note that not everyone with HMD will progress to the more advanced stages of the disease. The progression and severity of HMD can differ between individuals and can be influenced by various factors, including lifestyle, environmental factors, and treatment options. Regular eye examinations and appropriate management can help slow down the progression of the disease and preserve vision for as long as possible.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you are experiencing a condition called "amaurosis fugax." This is a temporary loss of vision in one eye that comes and goes. There are several possible causes for this symptom, including:

1. Retinal artery occlusion: A blockage or narrowing of the blood vessel supplying the retina can cause a sudden reduction in blood flow to the affected eye, leading to temporary vision loss.

2. Central retinal artery occlusion: A complete blockage of the central retinal artery can result in sudden and severe visual impairment.

3. Optic neuritis: Inflammation of the optic nerve can cause transient visual disturbances, including a decrease in visual acuity or loss of vision in one eye.

4. Migraine with aura: Some individuals with migraines may experience visual disturbances, such as decreased vision in one eye, prior to or during a headache episode.

5. Reflex action: The "smaller eye" sensation you described could be a reflex action triggered by the body's natural defense mechanism. When there is reduced blood flow to the eye, the body tries to redirect blood flow to the more important organ (the left eye in this case).

It is important to consult with an ophthalmologist for a compreh

The presence of water discharge from the eyes, along with a thick, semi-liquid discharge from the sides, suggests an infection in the conjunctiva, which is the thin clear tissue that covers the white part of the eye and lines the inner surface of the eyelids.

The heaviness in the eyes could be due to inflammation or irritation caused by the infection.

To confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of the conjunctivitis, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional, such as an ophthalmologist or an eye specialist. They will be able to examine your mother's eyes, take a detailed history, and perform any necessary tests to prescribe appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, it is important to avoid touching or rubbing the eyes to prevent spreading the infection to others. Encourage your mother to practice good hand hygiene and avoid sharing towels or other personal items until a proper diagnosis is made.

input: Hello doctor,I play games on my laptop for hours a day and after a few hours, my eyes become little blurry especially my left eye. So what kind of medication do I need?
raw_output:

So what kind of medication do I need?

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it appears that you are experiencing eye strain or fatigue. This is common when spending long hours in front of a screen, such as playing games on your laptop.

To alleviate your symptoms, I would recommend the following:

1. Take regular breaks: Every 20 minutes or so, look away from your screen and focus on an object that is at least 20 feet away for about 20 seconds. This exercise helps reduce eye strain.

2. Adjust screen settings: Make sure your screen brightness is set at a comfortable level. Reduce the blue light emitted by your laptop by using filters or software programs specifically designed for this purpose.

3. Improve lighting: Ensure that the room you are working in has adequate lighting. Avoid working in complete darkness or with excessively bright lights.

4. Use the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, take a break and look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds. This helps relax the eye muscles and reduces strain.

5. Blink frequently: When engrossed in activities like gaming, it's easy to forget to blink regularly. Consciously remind yourself to blink often to keep your eyes lubricated and reduce strain.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am a 31-year-old male with a history of closed globe injury in the right eye 10 years ago. At that time, my vision in the right eye was hand movements only and I was diagnosed with a macular injury. Three months later, my vision slowly improved to 6/36. However, my right eye started to deviate (exotropia) and I started experiencing diplopia. My main problem is diplopia. I have used prisms, but of no use. When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am a 31-year-old male with a history of closed globe injury in the right eye 10 years ago. At that time, my vision in the right eye was hand movements only and I was diagnosed with a macular injury. Three months later, my vision slowly improved to 6/36. However, my right eye started to deviate (exotropia) and I started experiencing diplopia. My main problem is diplopia. I have used prisms, but of no use. When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it appears that he is experiencing diplopia (double vision) as a result of a previous closed globe injury and macular injury in his right eye. The fact that his vision has improved over time does not seem to have resolved the diplopia.

Given the severity of the diplopia and its impact on daily activities, surgical intervention may be considered. Squint surgery, also known as strabismus surgery, aims to realign the eyes and reduce or eliminate the diplopia. This procedure can significantly improve visual acuity and quality of life for individuals with uncontrolled diplopia.

However, it is important to consider other factors before proceeding with surgery. A comprehensive eye examination by an ophthalmologist or an eye specialist would be beneficial to assess the extent of the deviation, evaluate the overall health of the eye, and determine the most appropriate treatment approach.

In addition to surgical options, there are non-surgical approaches that can help manage diplopia. These include wearing prism glasses, which can help redirect the eyes' alignment, or using patching therapy to strengthen the amblyopic eye. However, these methods may not fully address the underlying cause of the diplopia and may not provide a long-term solution compared to surgical intervention.

input: Hello doctor,I have an anal fissure, internal hemorrhoid, SRUS, and constipation. One year ago, I was suffering from a hard stool that was difficult to pass. Earlier this month, I went to another GI specialist who did a sigmoidoscopy and said that it is SRUS. He said that I should not finger evacuate the stools and gave me liquid paraffin and LoX cream. Now, my current situation is that it has been three days and I am very constipated and fatigued. The pain has subsided a little. However, I am not passing stools as I used to before. After I drink water or eat something, I get a vomiting sensation. I get anxiety and panic attacks as I am scared about my condition and do not know which doctor I should consult and what I should do. In the allopathic approach, the hormone needs to be taken for the rest of one\s life and I am a bit scared of it. It is possible I may also be diabetic and will need to treat this as well. raw_output:

Can these conditions be successfully dealt with through ayurvedic treatments alone?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide information on the possibilities of treating hypothyroidism and diabetes through Ayurveda.

Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones. The most common cause of hypothyroidism is an autoimmune disorder called Hashimoto's thyroiditis. In this condition, the immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to decreased hormone production.

While Ayurveda does have some approaches for managing hypothyroidism, it primarily focuses on addressing the root cause and promoting overall well-being rather than curing the condition. Treatment may involve herbal remedies, dietary changes, and lifestyle modifications. However, it is important to note that these approaches may not be sufficient for individuals with severe or advanced stages of hypothyroidism.

Regarding your concern about taking synthetic hormones for the rest of your life, it is understandable to have reservations. However, in cases of severe hypothyroidism, hormone replacement therapy with synthetic thyroid hormones is considered necessary to restore normal hormone levels and prevent complications. The decision to take hormones for life should be made in consultation with your healthcare provider, who can assess your specific situation and guide you

input: Hi doctor,We are trying for a baby for three months. I have been facing a couple of issues. I feel the symptoms of periods within 18 to 20 days of my previous cycle. My regular cycle was between 25 to 28 days before. I was taking Folvite (Folic acid tablet) but started using iron tablets for two months. Please let me know what could be the cause? Or is this normal?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hi doctor,We are trying for a baby for three months. I have been facing a couple of issues. I feel the symptoms of periods within 18 to 20 days of my previous cycle. My regular cycle was between 25 to 28 days before. I was taking Folvite (Folic acid tablet) but started using iron tablets for two months. Please let me know what could be the cause? Or is this normal?

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it is possible that your shorter menstrual cycle could be related to the change in your folic acid supplement. Folic acid plays a crucial role in the production of red blood cells, which are responsible for carrying oxygen to different parts of the body, including the uterus. When there is a deficiency in folic acid, it can lead to a decrease in the number of mature eggs released during ovulation, resulting in lighter or shorter menstrual cycles.

However, it is also important to consider other factors that could contribute to a shorter menstrual cycle. Stress, changes in weight or exercise habits, certain medications, and hormonal imbalances can all affect the regularity of your menstrual cycle.

To determine the exact cause of your shorter menstrual cycle, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation, consider all possible factors, and provide appropriate guidance or further testing if needed.

I eat and drink regularly. I work in a dusty environment. The dizziness is definitely associated with congestion. How can I stop it?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems that their stuffy nose is causing brief dizzy spells when they attempt to blow their nose. This indicates that the dizziness is likely related to the congestion and pressure in their nasal passages.

To address this issue, I would recommend the following:

1. Use saline nasal sprays or rinses: Saline solutions can help to moisturize and clear out the nasal passages, providing relief from congestion.

2. Use a humidifier: Adding moisture to the air can help prevent dryness in the nasal passages, which can contribute to congestion and dizziness.

3. Avoid blowing your nose too hard: While it may be tempting to forcefully blow your nose, this can actually make the congestion worse and lead to dizziness. Instead, gently pinch your nose and use nasal strips or a nasal dilator to assist with nasal breathing.

4. Consider using over-the-counter decongestants: If the congestion is severe, over-the-counter decongestant nasal sprays or oral medications may provide temporary relief. However, these should be used cautiously and according to the package instructions, as prolonged use can lead to rebound congestion.

raw_output:

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:

But, the doctor has told to get DNA test that is an NIPT test. Is it important? If level 1 and the double marker are fine then DNA and NIPT test should also be fine right?

### Response:Hello,

Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concerns regarding the DNA test during your wife's pregnancy.

The NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing) is a screening test that can detect certain chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. It analyzes cell-free fetal DNA present in the mother's blood. This test is typically recommended for high-risk pregnancies or when there are concerns about potential chromosomal abnormalities.

Based on the information provided, if both the level 1 scan and the double marker test results are normal, it suggests that the pregnancy is progressing normally. However, it does not rule out the possibility of chromosomal abnormalities entirely. In some cases, even if the initial screening tests are normal, advanced genetic testing like NIPT may still be recommended to provide further reassurance or detect any potential issues.

Therefore, I would advise you to follow your doctor's recommendation and proceed with the NIPT test. It can provide additional information and peace of mind, especially if there are any concerns about the pregnancy.

Please consult with your healthcare provider for further guidance and to discuss any specific concerns you may have.

input: Hello doctor,I have psoriasis for a long time for which I have been taking Methotrexate. Last week I got my iron studies and blood test done. My transferrin saturation, and total iron levels are low but hemoglobin is fine. Kindly advice.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your low transferrin saturation and total iron levels may be related to your long-term use of Methotrexate. Methotrexate is a medication commonly used to treat psoriasis, but it can also affect the production of red blood cells and cause anemia.

Low transferrin saturation indicates that there may not be enough transferrin protein available to transport iron in the bloodstream. Low total iron levels suggest a decreased amount of iron in the body. However, since your hemoglobin levels are fine, it indicates that your body is producing enough red blood cells to compensate for the low iron levels.

I would recommend discussing these results with your prescribing doctor or a hematologist. They will be able to assess your specific situation and determine the best course of action. It may involve adjusting the dosage of Methotrexate or exploring alternative treatment options to manage your psoriasis while addressing the low iron levels.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I have minor beta thalassemia which I got from my mother, but unlike her (asymptomatic), I have anemia symptoms like paleness, shortness of breath after the least effort, feeling tired all the time, broken nails and I want to know if it could be due to lack of iron? Could people with minor beta thalassemia also get iron deficiency anemia? Knowing that I get heavy cycles and my diet is very poor.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have minor beta thalassemia which I got from my mother, but unlike her (asymptomatic), I have anemia symptoms like paleness, shortness of breath after the least effort, feeling tired all the time, broken nails and I want to know if it could be due to lack of iron? Could people with minor beta thalassemia also get iron deficiency anemia? Knowing that I get heavy cycles and my diet is very poor.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that your anemia could be due to a lack of iron. Iron deficiency anemia is a common type of anemia and can occur in individuals with minor beta thalassemia. Thalassemia is a genetic blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, which is responsible for carrying oxygen in the blood. In beta thalassemia, there is a decrease in the production of beta-globin chains, leading to abnormal hemoglobin formation.

Iron is an essential component for the production of hemoglobin, and if there is insufficient iron available, it can result in decreased red blood cell production and subsequent anemia. Additionally, poor diet and heavy menstrual cycles can contribute to inadequate iron levels, further increasing the likelihood of developing iron deficiency anemia.

To confirm whether your symptoms are indeed due to iron deficiency anemia, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional who can perform appropriate diagnostic tests, such as a complete blood count (CBC) and iron studies. They will be able to provide a definitive diagnosis and recommend appropriate treatment options, which may include iron supplementation or dietary modifications.

input: Hi doctor,I have been with the same partner for 8 years now. During these all 8 years I have had several UTIs with some leading to severe kidney infections. Last week after almost two years of not having a UTI I felt the horrible symptoms again. When going to the doctors UTI urine test came back positive. Unfortunately two days later, the symptoms came back (please note that I had sex with my partner the day before) with burning sensation when urinating and painful when standing with the need to go toilet every 2 to 3 minutes. I went back to the clinic the same day to get it checked and take more antibiotics.But to my surprise, the urine test came back clear for UTI, and my symptoms disappeared. I have been diagnosed with Chlamydia at the beginning of this same relationship and was treated for it. My partner was also tested, but his results came back negative. input: Hello doctor,I am 42 years old and have been diagnosed with multiple uterine fibroids. Two of them are a little more than 3 cm at different places in the uterus. In the past, I have been operated for endometriosis level 4. As usual, the gynecologist is suggesting a hysterectomy. raw_output:

In the past, I have been operated for endometriosis level 4. As usual, the gynecologist is suggesting a hysterectomy. But since I am in my perimenopausal phase, can the fibroids shrink with medication? I have been suggested Fibroease.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that the uterine fibroids could shrink with medication during the perimenopausal phase. Fibroease is a medication commonly used to treat uterine fibroids. It contains a hormone called goserelin, which works by reducing the production of estrogen in the body. By reducing estrogen levels, Fibroease can help shrink or slow down the growth of uterine fibroids.

However, it is important to note that not all patients will experience fibroid shrinkage with medication. The response to treatment can vary from person to person. Additionally, if the fibroids are large or causing significant symptoms, surgical options such as a hysterectomy may still be necessary.

It would be best for the patient to discuss their specific situation with their gynecologist or a specialist in reproductive medicine to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for their fibroids.

She was 5 lbs 10 ounces at birth and was healthy (did not have to stay in the NICU). She hit all of her milestones in terms of rolling over, crawling and walking (walked at 14.5 months), but is a toe walker. Her left leg (to us) is weaker than her right and her left leg does not bend as much as her right leg. She began to speak around 10 months of age then her speech left. We came to find out she had chronic fluid and a month back she had tubes placed. I am hearing more vowel and consonants now but no true words yet. She makes fine eye contact. Her non-verbal communication is good. She responds to her name but not always. She is beginning to learn more of what we are saying, she plays with some toys, is not terribly social. Torsion, as well as infection, was ruled out.The exact incident occurred before few days. I did a urine test and another ultrasound. Torsion was ruled out once again. When the pain flared up again, I went to the doctor back. Again, I did an ultrasound, urine test, and blood test. Torsion and infection were ruled once again.The doctor pointed out a little bit of fluid around my testicle, and I had no pain. But, still, I have pain in my testicle. What was ruled out with these tests? From where does the pain arises?
raw_output:

Torsion, as well as infection, was ruled out.The exact incident occurred before few days. I did a urine test and another ultrasound. Torsion was ruled out once again. When the pain flared up again, I went to the doctor back. Again, I did an ultrasound, urine test, and blood test. Torsion and infection were ruled once again.The doctor pointed out a little bit of fluid around my testicle, and I had no pain. But, still, I have pain in my testicle. What was ruled out with these tests? From where does the pain arises?

### Response:Based on the information provided, the tests that were performed ruled out torsion and infection as the cause of your symptoms. Torsion refers to the twisting of the testicle, which can cause pain and may require immediate medical attention. Infection can also cause testicular pain.

The fluid around your testicle, as mentioned by the doctor, could be a result of an inflammatory condition called epididymitis, which can cause testicular pain and discomfort. Epididymitis can be caused by infection, such as a urinary tract infection, or other inflammatory conditions.

The pain that you are experiencing could be due to various factors, including irritation or inflammation of the testicular tissue itself. It is important to consult with your doctor to further evaluate the cause of your symptoms and determine the most appropriate treatment plan.

In your case, the RAST test results indicate that egg white, wheat, and oats are class 2 allergens, while milk and hazelnut are class 1 allergens. Class 0 indicates no allergenic response, while classes 1, 2, and 3 indicate increasing levels of allergic sensitivity.

These organizations set standards for various aspects of laboratory operations, including quality management systems, equipment calibration, personnel qualifications, and data management.

input: Hi doctor,I feel a strange glitch in my vision. It is quite big and takes up a large portion of my central vision. It is neither a shadow nor a flash, it looks like a greasy fingerprint smudge in my vision which disappears quickly. It happens when I blink, but mostly occurs when my eyes move quickly. I have had it for the past few days and I do not know if it is anything to be concerned about. Please help.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I feel a strange glitch in my vision. It is quite big and takes up a large portion of my central vision. It is neither a shadow nor a flash, it looks like a greasy fingerprint smudge in my vision which disappears quickly. It happens when I blink, but mostly occurs when my eyes move quickly. I have had it for the past few days and I do not know if it is anything to be concerned about. Please help.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, the symptoms you are experiencing could be related to a condition called floaters. Floaters are small specks or shapes that seem to float in your field of vision. They are actually tiny clumps of gel or cells inside the vitreous, which is a jelly-like substance that fills the back of your eye.

Floaters are generally harmless and common, especially as we age. However, if you suddenly notice an increase in the number of floaters, see flashing lights, or have a loss of peripheral vision, it could be a sign of a serious condition called retinal detachment. This occurs when the retina detaches from its normal position, which can cause vision loss and requires immediate medical attention.

I recommend scheduling an appointment with an ophthalmologist to have your eyes examined. They will be able to determine if your symptoms are due to floaters or if further investigation is needed. It's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to vision changes.

Meralgia paresthetica is a compression neuropathy that occurs when the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is compressed as it passes through the inguinal ligament. This condition is commonly associated with activities that involve prolonged sitting or repetitive leg movements, such as long-distance cycling or running.

input: Hello doctor, I think I am bipolar. Just a couple of weeks ago, I felt and was told by my friends that I was more energetic and crazy than usual. ### Response:Based on the symptoms you have described, it is possible that you may be experiencing bipolar disorder. Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings, including episodes of mania (elevated or irritable mood) and depression (low mood).

The symptoms you mentioned, such as increased energy, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, impulsivity, and feelings of hopelessness, are consistent with manic episodes commonly seen in individuals with bipolar disorder. On the other hand, your current state of feeling like no one cares and believing that you are faking your symptoms could be signs of depressive episodes.

It is important to note that a proper diagnosis can only be made by a qualified healthcare professional after a thorough evaluation and assessment. I would strongly recommend seeking help from a psychiatrist or mental health professional who can provide a comprehensive assessment and develop an appropriate treatment plan for you. They will be able to address your concerns, provide guidance, and potentially prescribe medication if necessary.

Remember, reaching out for support is an important step towards understanding and managing your condition.

The testes require a constant supply of oxygen and hormones for proper functioning. Reduced blood flow may negatively impact the DNA replication and repair abilities of spermatogonial cells, which are responsible for producing sperm. This can lead to an accumulation of genetic errors or mutations in the sperm. These mutations can then be passed on to offspring, increasing the risk of certain genetic disorders or abnormalities. It is important to maintain adequate blood flow to the testes to ensure proper sperm quality and minimize the risk of spontaneous mutations.

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with information about the keto diet.

1. Safety: The keto diet is generally safe for healthy individuals when followed properly. However, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional or registered dietitian before starting any new diet to ensure that it is suitable for you and to address any potential risks or underlying medical conditions that may affect your ability to follow the diet safely.

2. Weight loss: The keto diet can be an effective way to lose weight, especially in the short term. It involves consuming a very low carbohydrate, high-fat diet that causes your body to enter a metabolic state called ketosis, where it starts burning fat for fuel instead of carbohydrates. This can lead to weight loss, especially if you are in a calorie deficit. However, it is important to note that sustainable weight loss requires a combination of a healthy diet, regular physical activity, and lifestyle changes.

It is also worth mentioning that individual responses to the keto diet may vary, and some people may experience side effects such as initial flu-like symptoms, digestive issues, or difficulty sleeping due to changes in hormone levels. These side effects are often temporary and improve as your body adjusts to the new way of eating

input: Hi doctor,I have a squint in my right eye and it has moved outwards. I do not have a proper vision in my right. I cannot see clearly through my right eye; even I recognize thing pretty hard. I want to know whether it can be corrected, so that both my eyes work together. I am confused as I am now 26 years old. Is the correction going to be difficult at this age? I am looking up for a second opinion from you. Thank you.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I have a squint in my right eye and it has moved outwards. I do not have a proper vision in my right. I cannot see clearly through my right eye; even I recognize thing pretty hard. I want to know whether it can be corrected, so that both my eyes work together. I am confused as I am now 26 years old. Is the correction going to be difficult at this age? I am looking up for a second opinion from you. Thank you.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you have a condition called strabismus, which is causing your squint and poor vision in your right eye. Strabismus refers to any misalignment or turning of the eyes, and it can affect one or both eyes.

It is important to consult with an ophthalmologist or an eye specialist for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They will perform a comprehensive eye examination, including visual acuity tests, eye muscle evaluations, and possibly some imaging studies to determine the underlying cause of your squint.

The treatment options for strabismus depend on the specific cause and severity of your condition. In some cases, vision therapy or glasses may be sufficient to correct the alignment of the eyes. In more severe cases, surgery may be required to reposition the muscles of the eye or adjust the alignment.

Correction of strabismus can be challenging at any age, but it is certainly not impossible. With appropriate treatment and therapy, significant improvements in vision and eye alignment can be achieved.

I would recommend seeking a second opinion from an experienced eye specialist who can evaluate your specific case and provide you with personalized advice and treatment options.

There are several management strategies for IBS:

1. Dietary modifications: Certain foods and drinks can trigger symptoms in individuals with IBS. It is recommended to identify and avoid these triggers, which may include fatty or fried foods, caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods, dairy products, and artificial sweeteners. input: Hi doctor,I am a boy, 18 years old. My right knee has clicking sound without any pain. Please help me out of this. Is this symptom of any big disease? Tell me some things to cure this.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am a boy, 18 years old. My right knee has clicking sound without any pain. Please help me out of this. Is this symptom of any big disease? Tell me some things to cure this.

### Response:Based on the information you provided, a clicking sound in the knee without any pain can be caused by various conditions. It is important to evaluate the underlying cause in order to determine the appropriate treatment.

One possible cause of a clicking knee is a condition called patellofemoral pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain and discomfort around or behind the kneecap (patella). This condition can result from overuse, improper biomechanics, or muscle imbalances. Treatment options for patellofemoral pain syndrome include physical therapy, pain medications, and modifying activities that aggravate the symptoms.

Another possible cause of a clicking knee is iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS), which occurs when the iliotibial band, a thick band of tissue on the outside of the thigh, becomes tight or inflamed. This can cause pain and a clicking sensation on the outside of the knee joint. Treatment for ITBS often includes rest, physical therapy, stretching exercises, anti-inflammatory medications, and occasionally, orthopedic interventions such as braces or injections.

In some cases, a clicking knee may be due to meniscal tear or other structural abnormalities within the knee joint. These conditions may require further evaluation and potentially surgical

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,If I get my wisdom teeth extracted, do my second molars shift in that empty spot?

### Response:Yes, when you have your wisdom teeth extracted, it is common for your second molars to shift in the empty space left behind. This is known as dental migration. The second molars may shift towards the empty socket or may simply tilt or rotate. However, not all cases of dental migration are significant and may not require any treatment. It is important to follow up with your dentist or orthodontist after the extraction to monitor any changes and determine if any further action is needed.

input: Hello doctor,I suspect I may have tapeworms. How can I be sure and what can I do to get rid of them?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I suspect I may have tapeworms. How can I be sure and what can I do to get rid of them?

### Response:Hello, I'm sorry to hear that you suspect you may have tapeworms. To be sure and to get rid of them, I would recommend the following steps:

1. Physical examination: A physical examination can help determine if there are any signs of tapeworm infestation, such as abdominal pain, loss of appetite, or weight loss.

2. Stool sample analysis: A stool sample analysis can be done to check for the presence of tapeworm eggs or cysts. This can help confirm the diagnosis.

3. Blood tests: Blood tests may also be conducted to check for anemia, which can be caused by heavy bleeding from the intestines due to tapeworm infection.

4. Treatment options:
   - Medications: Depending on the type of tapeworm infection, your doctor may prescribe antibiotics or antiparasitic medications to treat the infection.
   - Hygiene measures: If the infection is due to contaminated food or water, your doctor may advise certain hygiene measures like washing hands thoroughly and cooking food properly.

It's important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

It's important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

input: Hi doctor,My periods started 14 days before and I had sex eight days back. Should I take pills after unsafe sex? If yes, what is the procedure to take I-pill?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My periods started 14 days before and I had sex eight days back. Should I take pills after unsafe sex? If yes, what is the procedure to take I-pill?

### Response:As a doctor, I would recommend that you take emergency contraception (EC) also known as the "morning-after pill" or I-pill. The I-pill is a safe and effective method to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex.

To take the I-pill, follow these steps:
1. Find a healthcare provider or pharmacy that sells the I-pill.
2. Ask for a pack of I-pills and confirm the brand name and dosage with the pharmacist or healthcare provider.
3. Take the I-pill as soon as possible, within 72 hours (three days) of unprotected sex.
4. Swallow one pill whole with a glass of water.
5. Within a few hours, you may experience some side effects such as abdominal pain, nausea, or dizziness. These are usually mild and temporary.
6. If you vomit within two hours of taking the pill, you should take another pill without delay.
7. You can resume your regular activities immediately after taking the I-pill.

It is important to note that the I-pill is most effective when taken within 12 hours of unprotected sex, but it still provides some level of protection even if taken up to 72 hours later. However, the sooner you take it, the better

input: Hello doctor,I had an X-ray last Thursday and I got the result today. It says I have fibrosis in my right upper lobe. I had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis two years back and I took a six months medication and I am done with it. I just want to ask if fibrosis can be cured if I take medication and do exercise daily and eat healthy foods?
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:

I had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis two years back and I took a six months medication and I am done with it. I just want to ask if fibrosis can be cured if I take medication and do exercise daily and eat healthy foods?

### Response:Hello,

Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concerns about the X-ray result indicating fibrosis in your right upper lobe. Based on the information provided, it appears that you had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis and have completed a six-month medication course.

Fibrosis is a condition characterized by the scarring or thickening of lung tissue. In some cases, fibrosis can be reversed or improved with appropriate treatment and lifestyle modifications. However, it's important to note that the extent and severity of fibrosis can vary from person to person.

To address the question of whether fibrosis can be cured through medication, exercise, and healthy eating, let's break it down into each component:

1. Medication: It is crucial to continue taking any prescribed medications as directed by your healthcare provider. These may include medications to manage any underlying conditions such as tuberculosis or other respiratory infections. Adhering to the prescribed medication regimen can help control symptoms and slow down the progression of fibrosis.

2. Exercise: Regular exercise is beneficial for overall lung health and can contribute to improved respiratory function. However, it is essential to consult with your healthcare provider or a pulmonologist before starting an exercise program,

input: Hi doctor,I am 9 months pregnant, and I have some doubts with my recent free T3, T4, and TSH levels. My Triiodothyronine total (T3) is 208.57. What is it? Is it something to worry or is it normal? My TSH is under control, and it is 2.63 now.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am 9 months pregnant, and I have some doubts with my recent free T3, T4, and TSH levels. My Triiodothyronine total (T3) is 208.57. What is it? Is it something to worry or is it normal? My TSH is under control, and it is 2.63 now.

### Response:Based on your description, your Triiodothyronine total (T3) level of 208.57 is considered high. The normal range for T3 is typically between 80-200 picograms per deciliter (pg/dl). A level of 208.57 is above the upper limit of the normal range, indicating an elevated T3 level.

Elevated T3 levels can be caused by various factors, including maternal thyroid disease, gestational hypertension, or an overactive thyroid gland. It is important to consult with your healthcare provider to further evaluate the cause of your high T3 level and determine appropriate management.

Your TSH level of 2.63 is within the normal range, which indicates that your thyroid gland is functioning normally. TSH is the hormone produced by the pituitary gland that regulates thyroid hormone production. A TSH level between 2.5-10 mU/L is considered normal during pregnancy.

It is recommended that you schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider to discuss your T3 and TSH levels in detail. They will be able to provide you with more specific guidance based on your individual situation.

It is recommended that you schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider to discuss your T3 and TSH levels in detail. They will be able to provide you with more specific guidance based on your individual situation.

input: Hello doctor,I had a chest x-ray and chest ct scan done. And they both came back normal. If I had emphysema would it have shown up on one of those two tests?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had a chest x-ray and chest ct scan done. And they both came back normal. If I had emphysema would it have shown up on one of those two tests?

### Response:Hello,

As a medical expert, I can provide some information regarding your question. Emphysema is a lung condition characterized by the destruction of the air sacs in the lungs, leading to difficulty in breathing. Chest x-ray and chest CT scan are imaging tests that can help detect certain lung conditions, including emphysema.

Both chest x-ray and chest CT scan are useful in diagnosing emphysema; however, a chest x-ray may not provide as clear images as a chest CT scan. A chest x-ray can show if there is any abnormality in the lungs, such as bullae (enlarged air sacs) or traction bronchiectasis (narrowing of the airways due to scarring). A chest CT scan, on the other hand, provides more detailed images and can help identify emphysema more accurately.

Therefore, if you have emphysema, it is possible that it could be seen on either a chest x-ray or a chest CT scan. However, the sensitivity and specificity of these tests in detecting emphysema may vary depending on individual factors and the severity of the disease. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your symptoms, medical history, and test results to make an accurate diagnosis.

I hope this information

input: Hi doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman and last month I was hospitalized with a necrotizing soft tissue infection on my thigh. I had two debridement surgeries and was discharged after 5 days. I was treated with about 4 IV antibiotics. I do not remember them all, I recall seeing Vancomycin and Penicillin. I was told that the infection was not MRSA, but a "slower moving bacteria" they did not tell me what it was. I was swabbed for MRSA in my nose and butt before both surgeries and was told I did not have it. For the last day of my stay, I had a roommate who had a bad MRSA infection on her butt and sometimes had diarrhea incontinence during dressing changes. I had no physical contact with her, but we had the same nurse. I was discharged with a five day course of Augmentin.The wound has been healing very well and has not gotten infected, but three weeks after discharge I got an abscess under my arm. I went to an urgent care and was prescribed Clindamycin and told to return in three days for drainage. The abscess did not improve or get worse over the three days. I got it drained and was prescribed Augmentin and told to also continue the clindamycin. That was a week ago and the wound is healing well. They called today and said cultures show it was MRSA and they prescribed Bactrim and told me to stop the other antibiotics.I am feeling devastated by this and wanting to understand why it happened. Could I have gotten it in the hospital? I am concerned that it will not go away. Are those swabs at the hospital conclusive and mean for sure I did not have MRSA a month ago? I have never had any medical problems before and these experiences have been very frightening. Is there anything else I can do to prevent recurrence? I have read about everything from bleach baths and hibiclens to antibiotics in the nose.

It is important to note that MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, is a type of bacteria that is resistant to many commonly used antibiotics.

input: Hello doctor,I am a sufferer of hemiplegic migraine. However, I had unusual collapses three months back. The first one was 40 minutes; I could not recall the whole of that period. I came back with an injured knee and felt dazed. I was fine after around two hours. The next day, I felt pressure in my head and as though I was about to die. I then could not recall getting home or the rest of the night. I was fine in the morning. Two days later, I felt horrendous pain in my head, felt like I was swimming, then tried to go home and again could not recall from deciding to go home to around two hours later and I was foggy for the rest of the night. I have had constant pain in the left side of my head above the temple for four years. It does not go. However, In the past two weeks, I have felt like it is throbbing and at times about to burst out. I was meant to see my neurologist three months back, but his receptionist did not follow the recommendation, and now I am unsure whether to have the tests done. I feel like we are playing with my life. Usually, I am pretty relaxed about the possibilities and know it is a migraine. But this feels different. This feels like intense throbbing above my ear from the temple along towards the back of my head, with a pain in my ear to just behind my jaw under my ear. My instinct says that an aneurysm needs ruling out. I do not know if I am just upset because it feels so different and this pressure is intense. It is a weird feeling. I currently take Sumatriptan as needed.Please, can you advise what to do? As it stands the next neuro appointment is after four months, added complication is that I have been breathless and unable to climb stairs without stopping and panting for past four months. I am having heart tests on the weekend. But, what do I do about my brain?

To cure or improve premature ejaculation, I recommend the following steps:

3. Behavioral techniques: Practice delayed ejaculation techniques. Kegel exercises can also help strengthen the pelvic muscles, which can contribute to better control.

4. Medications: In some

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing severe constipation. It is important to identify the underlying cause of your constipation and make appropriate lifestyle changes. Here are some suggestions:

1. Increase fiber intake: While fiber supplements can be helpful, it is also important to increase your daily fiber intake from fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. Aim for at least 25-30 grams of fiber per day.

2. Stay hydrated: Drinking enough water is crucial for maintaining regular bowel movements. Aim to drink at least 8-10 cups (64-80 ounces) of water per day.

3. Exercise regularly: Physical activity promotes healthy digestion and prevents constipation. Engage in aerobic exercises such as walking, swimming, or cycling for at least 30 minutes most days of the week.

4. Avoid excessive dairy products: Some individuals may experience constipation as a result of consuming excessive dairy products. Consider reducing your intake of milk, cheese, and yogurt if you notice an improvement in your symptoms after doing so.

5. Manage stress levels: Stress and anxiety can contribute to constipation
