An initial urine culture was normal according to my doctor. Yesterday, I performed another dipstick and urine culture. The dipstick was normal, and early urine microscopy showed 10 to 100 white cell count. We are waiting for the cultures to return. Due to the result of the white cell count, my doctor said it would be worth a try to undergo a 5-day course of antibiotics (Keflex).Today is my third day of antibiotic treatment, symptoms are largely the same. Today, I attempted to hold my bladder. It felt fine in the morning but as the day went on, my symptoms returned and I am finding it harder to hold my bladder. Also, for the first time, I tried going for a run. The entire time I felt a heaviness in my bladder and felt a strong urge to urinate, even though I went before my run began. What do you think could be going on? My doctor believes that it is either a UTI, or most likely, a hypersensitive bladder due to exam stress. However, there have been days where I have not felt stress at all yet symptoms have continued. I am really worried as I want to go back to work in five days and I do not think I will be able to manage the way things are at the moment. My family doctor does think this will settle down now that I have finished exams. Do you think there is a chance it could? I have mentioned this query to another doctor online, and he believed it may be due to an overactive bladder. However, since I am relatively young to receive this diagnosis, I wanted a second opinion, if that is alright. Do you think this could be OAB? I am worried that it could be something serious, like multiple sclerosis. One and a half years ago, I had an episode of sudden onset numbness in one arm and fearing the same thing, I ended up having an MRI of my brain and lumbar spine which both came back negative. Hello doctor,I am suffering from pain in my mouth. It is like sensitivity pain. I cannot say it is pain exactly, it is irritating a lot. No pain in teeth. It is feeling like itching in my gums (middle of the teeth). Please tell me what can I do.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing dental sensitivity. Dental sensitivity can be caused by a variety of factors such as brushing too hard, using harsh mouthwash, or having exposed tooth roots due to gum recession.

Here are a few recommendations to help alleviate your symptoms:

1. Use a soft-bristle toothbrush: Brushing gently with a softer toothbrush can minimize the abrasion on your teeth and gums.
2. Avoid acidic and sugary foods and drinks: Acidic and sugary substances can contribute to tooth decay and sensitivity. Limit your intake of these foods and beverages.
3. Rinse with warm saltwater: Rinse your mouth with warm saltwater several times a day. This can help reduce inflammation and promote healing.
4. Use a desensitizing toothpaste: Toothpastes specifically formulated for sensitive teeth can provide relief by reducing the exposure of your teeth to harsh acids and stimulating the growth of protective enamel.
5. Visit your dentist: It would be best to consult with a dentist for a thorough evaluation. They may recommend additional treatments such as fluoride gel applications or dental restorations if necessary.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I got a stroke but I do not know how to explain it. Twice I was bleeding along with the stroke. One type of bleeding was chronic and the other one was acute. I would like to know which type of bleeding is dangerous? And also explain the reason for the same.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I got a stroke but I do not know how to explain it. Twice I was bleeding along with the stroke. One type of bleeding was chronic and the other one was acute. I would like to know which type of bleeding is dangerous? And also explain the reason for the same.

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it sounds like you experienced a hemorrhagic stroke. This is different from an ischemic stroke, which is more common and occurs when there is a blockage in a blood vessel supplying the brain.

Hemorrhagic strokes are caused by bleeding in or around the brain. The bleeding can be chronic, meaning it has been present for some time, or acute, meaning it occurred recently. Among the two types of bleeding you mentioned, the chronic bleeding is generally considered less dangerous compared to the acute bleeding.

The chronic bleeding refers to an older hematoma or collection of blood that has been present in the brain for some time. Although it may cause symptoms similar to a stroke, such as weakness or difficulty speaking, it is generally less severe and less likely to cause permanent damage than an acute bleed.

On the other hand, acute bleeding refers to new bleeding that has occurred within the past few hours or days. It can be caused by a ruptured blood vessel, such as a weakened blood vessel that ruptures or a brain tumor that causes bleeding. Acute bleeding is considered more dangerous because it can expand rapidly and cause significant damage to brain tissue. It can also lead to increased pressure within the skull, which can be life-threatening.

It

input: Hi doctor,I am 31 years old. I have gaps between my teeth. Can it be closed? By which process can it be closed?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am 31 years old. I have gaps between my teeth. Can it be closed? By which process can it be closed?

### Response:Yes, gaps between teeth can be closed through a process called orthodontics. Orthodontics is the branch of dentistry that deals with aligning and straightening teeth to improve their appearance and function. There are several techniques that can be used to close gaps between teeth, including:

1. Braces: These are metal brackets that are attached to the teeth and connected by wires. The wires are gradually adjusted to shift the teeth into their correct position.

2. Invisalign: This is a clear aligner system that uses a series of custom-made plastic trays to gradually move the teeth into place. Unlike braces, Invisalign trays are removed for eating and brushing teeth.

3. Dental bonding: This involves applying a tooth-colored filling material to the surface of the tooth to fill in the gap. It can also be used to reshape or lengthen teeth.

4. Orthodontic implants: These are small titanium posts that are surgically placed into the jaw to act as anchors for braces or other orthodontic appliances.

5. Laser dentistry: In some cases, lasers can be used to reshape teeth, remove tooth decay, or tighten brackets during orthodontic treatment.

The choice of treatment depends on various factors such as

input: Hi doctor,I am 21 and suffering from tinnitus from last four months. The sound in the ears is not constant. It is changing. My doctor told me this is due to cold and prescribed some antibiotics. But it did not work. So he told me to visit an ENT specialist. After visiting an ENT specialist, he told me my ears are fine but I should do an audiogram. And also given me some antibiotics. There was no hearing loss in the audiogram. And the medicines also did not work. Then I again visited the doctor. This time he told me there is nothing to worry about and sent me back home. What I want to ask is, if there are any other tests that could detect why this is happening and how this could be treated?

There are several potential causes for pulsatile tinnitus. One possible cause is an abnormal blood flow within the blood vessels near the inner ear. This could be due to conditions such as high blood pressure, blood vessel disorders, or certain tumors. Another possible cause is involuntary muscle contractions in the middle ear, leading to abnormal vibrations and subsequent perception of sound.

input: Hello doctor,I had both my thyroid glands removed eight years ago, and a small amount was left (in the size of half of my small nail). Since then, I am getting my blood test done every year, which comes back normal. I do not understand this as everybody needs two thyroid glands to work properly, and a small amount of the gland is not enough to do the job. I suffer from tiredness, weight gain, and insomnia over these years.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had both my thyroid glands removed eight years ago, and a small amount was left (in the size of half of my small nail). Since then, I am getting my blood test done every year, which comes back normal. I do not understand this as everybody needs two thyroid glands to work properly, and a small amount of the gland is not enough to do the job. I suffer from tiredness, weight gain, and insomnia over these years.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems that they are experiencing symptoms of hypothyroidism despite having a small amount of thyroid tissue remaining. The thyroid gland plays a crucial role in regulating metabolism and hormone production. While it is true that everyone needs two thyroid glands to work properly, in certain cases, even a small amount of thyroid tissue can be sufficient for basic function.

However, the patient's symptoms of tiredness, weight gain, and insomnia are consistent with hypothyroidism, which occurs when the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones. This can result in a slower metabolism, leading to weight gain and fatigue. Insomnia can also be associated with hypothyroidism.

It is important to note that the normal blood test results may not always accurately reflect the actual functioning of the thyroid gland. In this case, further evaluation by a healthcare professional, such as an endocrinologist, may be necessary to assess the patient's thyroid function more comprehensively. They may consider additional tests, such as measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels, free thyroxine (T4) levels, and possibly triiodothyronine (T3) levels to evaluate thyroid hormone levels more accurately.

input: Hello doctor,I am getting my wisdom teeth out and was told I will be under IV sedation, but I did not sign a consent to that, just anesthesia. So, I called and asked them about it. They said I will be asleep, but if they ask me to raise my hand, I will be able to do that. What on earth are they giving me? I want to be asleep during the entire procedure. Will IV sedation do that?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am getting my wisdom teeth out and was told I will be under IV sedation, but I did not sign a consent to that, just anesthesia. So, I called and asked them about it. They said I will be asleep, but if they ask me to raise my hand, I will be able to do that. What on earth are they giving me? I want to be asleep during the entire procedure. Will IV sedation do that?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you are scheduled for IV sedation for your wisdom tooth extraction. IV sedation is a type of anesthesia that allows you to be conscious and awake during the procedure but in a relaxed and drowsy state. It provides a level of sedation where you may not remember the details of the surgery but will still be able to respond to commands such as raising your hand.

IV sedation works by administering medications through a vein, allowing the drugs to quickly and effectively reach your bloodstream. This provides a consistent and controlled level of sedation throughout the procedure.

Therefore, if you are told that you will be asleep during the entire procedure and only need to raise your hand when asked, it is likely that you are receiving IV sedation.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 32 year old female, and I weigh 57 kg. I am work in a bank, which keeps me out of home from 9 AM to 7 PM. I was diagnosed with PCOS, and I have a 1.5 mm intramural fibroid on the posterior wall of the uterus since two years. I am taking Glyciphage SR 500 since then, and it has kept my period as well as ovulation regular. My menstrual cycle is 28 to 31 days now. My husband is 33 years old, and he weighs 72 kg, and his job keeps him away from home for 12 hours. He is suffering from erectile dysfunction from last year. His semen analysis revealed slow sperm, and he has been on Edon and Maxoza since three months.We went for IUI last month, and my husband has 10 million motile sperm count. The fertility specialist at the clinic told it is too low for IUI and suggested IVF with ICSI since IUI is only time and money loss. Is it necessary to do IVF with ICSI in our case? Since I have PCOS, can I suffer from OHSS during IVF? I am a working woman, do I need to take long breaks from the job while going IVF treatment? Can I go for single embryo transfer? Is bed rest needed after embryo transfer or during the entire IVF procedure?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:

I was diagnosed with PCOS, and I have a 1.5 mm intramural fibroid on the posterior wall of the uterus since two years. I am taking Glyciphage SR 500 since then, and it has kept my period as well as ovulation regular. My menstrual cycle is 28 to 31 days now. My husband is 33 years old, and he weighs 72 kg, and his job keeps him away from home for 12 hours. He is suffering from erectile dysfunction from last year. His semen analysis revealed slow sperm, and he has been on Edon and Maxoza since three months.We went for IUI last month, and my husband has 10 million motile sperm count. The fertility specialist at the clinic told it is too low for IUI and suggested IVF with ICSI since IUI is only time and money loss. Is it necessary to do IVF with ICSI in our case? Since I have PCOS, can I suffer from OHSS during IVF? I am a working woman, do I need to take long breaks from the job while going IVF treatment? Can I go for single embryo transfer? Is bed rest needed after embryo transfer or during the entire IVF procedure?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your husband has been diagnosed with erectile dysfunction and his semen analysis revealed slow sperm. To address these issues, he has been prescribed Edon and Maxoza.

In terms of your own medical history, you mentioned that you were diagnosed with PCOS and have a 1.5 mm intramural fibroid on the posterior wall of the uterus. It is mentioned that Glyciphage SR 500 has been prescribed to manage your symptoms and keep your period and ovulation regular.

Now, regarding the suggestion of IVF with ICSI, it is important to consider that the fertility specialist recommended this course of action because the motile sperm count for your husband was 10 million, which they deemed too low for IUI. ICSI, which stands for intracytoplasmic sperm injection, involves directly injecting a single healthy sperm into an egg to facilitate fertilization.

While IVF with ICSI may be recommended in cases where there are concerns about sperm quality or quantity, the final decision should be made after further evaluation and discussion between you, your husband, and your fertility specialist. It would be beneficial to discuss the potential risks and benefits, success rates, and any other concerns you may have regarding IVF with ICSI.

Reg

Hi doctor, I am having skin problems for the two months where pimples are like faint and after it disappears that spot becomes black. Please help.

### Response:Based on the description you provided, it seems like you may be experiencing a condition called post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation. This occurs when the pigment in the skin becomes darkened after an inflammatory skin condition, such as acne or a pimple, has healed.

To help reduce the appearance of these dark spots, I would recommend the following:

1. Avoid picking or popping your pimples: This can worsen the inflammation and increase the risk of scarring and hyperpigmentation.
2. Use gentle skincare products: Avoid products with harsh chemicals or ingredients that can irritate the skin. Opt for gentle cleansers, moisturizers, and sunscreens.
3. Use non-comedogenic makeup: Makeup that is specifically formulated for oily skin can clog pores and contribute to the development of acne and subsequent hyperpigmentation.
4. Protect your skin from sun exposure: UV rays can darken the skin and worsen hyperpigmentation. Use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher daily, and seek shade during peak sun hours.
5. Consider professional treatments: Certain professional procedures, such as chemical peels or microdermab

input: Hello doctor,I am an epilepsy patient. I got seizure before three weeks. There was a brain trauma nine months back. The CT and MRI showed only tumor and no other problem. Last week, the EEG report showed normal. How to find whether the seizure is caused by the tumor or by the trauma or both?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am an epilepsy patient. I got seizure before three weeks. There was a brain trauma nine months back. The CT and MRI showed only tumor and no other problem. Last week, the EEG report showed normal. How to find whether the seizure is caused by the tumor or by the trauma or both?

### Response:As an epilepsy patient with a history of brain trauma, it is important to determine the cause of your seizures. To find out whether the seizure is caused by the tumor or by the trauma, or both, a thorough evaluation is needed. Here are the steps you can take:

1. Consult with your neurologist: Schedule an appointment with your neurologist who specializes in epilepsy. They will review your medical history, including the details of your previous brain trauma and any imaging results.

2. Reassess the brain imaging: Request that your previous CT and MRI scans be reviewed by a radiologist. They will check for any abnormalities in the images, such as any changes in the tumor or any new findings related to the trauma.

3. Consider additional tests: Depending on the findings from the imaging review, your neurologist may recommend further tests. This could include an electroencephalogram (EEG) to monitor brain activity, blood tests to check for metabolic imbalances, or a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for infections or abnormalities.

4. Review the clinical picture: Your neurologist will consider all the available information, including your symptoms, medical history, and test results

Hello doctor,I am on a holiday. I wish to delay my period. Kindly advice.

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide you with some options to help delay your period. However, it's important to note that these methods may not be suitable for everyone and it's always best to consult with a healthcare professional before trying anything new. Here are a few options:

1. Birth control pills: Taking birth control pills can help regulate your menstrual cycle and delay your period. It is advisable to start taking the pill at least one week before your expected period date.

2. Hormonal intrauterine device (IUD): A hormonal IUD, such as Mirena, can be inserted to postpone your period for several years. This method works by releasing a small amount of hormone into the uterus to regulate your menstrual flow.

3. Combined oral contraceptives (COCs): Taking COCs, such as Yasmin or Yaz, can also help regulate your menstrual cycle and delay your period. These medications contain synthetic hormones that can prevent ovulation and delay the onset of your next period.

4. Progestin-releasing intrauterine device (IUD): A progestin-releasing IUD, like Skyla or Liletta, can be inserted to postpone your period for several years.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am a 24-year-male. My nose is growing towards the left side, and I want to know about rhinoplasty.

### Response:Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your nasal deformity. Rhinoplasty is a surgical procedure that can help reshape and correct the structure of the nose. It is commonly performed to improve aesthetics, correct breathing difficulties, or correct structural abnormalities.

During the consultation, your plastic surgeon will evaluate your nose and discuss your concerns and goals. They may also ask you questions about your medical history and any medications you are currently taking.

Rhinoplasty can be performed either using open or closed techniques. In an open technique, incisions are made across the columella (the strip of tissue between the nostrils), while in a closed technique, incisions are made within the nostrils alone.

The specific approach used will depend on various factors such as the extent of the desired changes and the surgeon's preference. Your surgeon will explain the advantages and disadvantages of each technique and help you choose the best option for you.

During the surgery, the skin and soft tissues of the nose are carefully separated from the bone and cartilage. The bone may be reshaped, and the cartilage may be removed or resized. In some cases, additional techniques like septoplasty (correcting the septum) or turbinate reduction may be performed to improve airflow.

### Response:Hello! I'm sorry to hear that your vision has been worsening despite living a healthy lifestyle. Myopia, or nearsightedness, can be caused by several factors including genetics, age, and certain environmental conditions. While you may have been practicing good habits, it's important to note that myopia can still progress even with a healthy lifestyle.

Here are some additional steps you can take to potentially slow down the progression of myopia:

1. Regular eye exercises: Certain eye exercises and techniques, such as palming, focusing on distant objects, and using a computer screen with a blue light filter, may help reduce myopia progression.

2. Outdoor activities: Spending more time outdoors in natural light has been associated with slower myopia progression. Increase your time spent outdoors, especially during the day.

3. Protect your eyes: Wear sunglasses that block 100% of UVA and UVB rays when spending time outdoors, as excessive exposure to sunlight can contribute to myopia progression.

4. Avoid close work: Minimize near work activities, such as reading or using digital screens for long periods, especially up close. Take regular breaks and practice focusing on objects at

input: Hi,I sprained my ankle while playing soccer. The ball hit the outside of my foot, causing my ankle to turn inward, and it popped few times. I also landed on it sideways in the same position. The doctor put me on crutches and a splint, which I only used for a day. It has been a week since I sprained it, there is still the pain in the top part of the ankle. The swelling went from none, to swollen to little swelling. I can play on it, but sometimes I feel pain. I have gone to my chiropractor twice, and it is still very tender around the top part of the ankle and the side of the leg, where those ligaments go upward. There is still slight pain while pointing my foot and turning it outward.My main concern is when I am sitting with my legs on the table, and when I try turning my ankle inward, I feel as though something in my ankle is shifting (like something is dislocated). My chiropractor tried adjusting the ankle, and it popped, but it did not affect the dislocated feeling. I have asked other people who I know have sprained their ankle, but they said they have never felt that. Should I be concerned? I am currently taking Advil.

3. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): Working with a therapist

input: Hi doctor,I want to know about body lift surgery procedure. I have lost weight of 50 kilograms. I want to get a full body life. How many surgeries do I need? How are they divided? How much time does it take for recovery?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I want to know about body lift surgery procedure. I have lost weight of 50 kilograms. I want to get a full body life. How many surgeries do I need? How are they divided? How much time does it take for recovery?

### Response:Body lift surgery is a procedure that involves removing excess skin and fat from the body, specifically targeting areas affected by weight loss or aging. The number of surgeries required depends on the extent of skin laxity and the specific areas being addressed. In your case, since you have lost weight and want a full body lift, it is likely that multiple surgical procedures will be needed.

Body lift surgeries are typically divided into different regions of the body. The most common approach is to perform a lower body lift, which includes procedures such as a belt lipectomy (removal of excess skin from the lower abdomen) and thigh lift (removal of excess skin from the inner thighs). This surgery can address the lower half of the body.

Additionally, an upper body lift may be recommended to address excess skin on the chest, arms, and back. This procedure involves a combination of liposuction and removal of excess skin.

Recovery time varies depending on the individual and the extent of the surgery. It is important to follow your surgeon's post-operative instructions for wound care, medication, and activity restrictions. Generally, it takes about 2-3 weeks for most of the swelling to subside, but complete recovery can take several months.

It is essential to consult with a qualified plastic surgeon who can assess your specific situation

Jock itch is caused by a fungal infection, usually due to an overgrowth of the fungus Malassezia. This infection can occur on various parts of the body, including the penis and forehead.

The itching and presence of white tiny particles on the skin could be indicative of this fungal infection. To confirm the diagnosis and obtain an appropriate treatment, it would be best to consult a healthcare professional, such as a dermatologist. They will be able to examine your skin and provide a specific diagnosis.

In the meantime, you can try some self-care measures to help alleviate the symptoms. These include keeping the affected areas clean and dry, avoiding tight-fitting clothing that can trap moisture, and using mild soaps when bathing. It's also recommended to avoid sharing towels or clothing with others, as the fungus can spread that way.

As for the solution, your dermatologist may prescribe an antifungal medication, such as clotrimazole or miconazole, in the form of creams, powders, or oral pills. They may also recommend using over-the-counter antifungal

I am now in more pain than I was before the operation. My testicle thorns with pain constantly and I have stabbing pain on hernia side. It feels like someone is sticking a bottle in me. I am struggling to walk very far, climb stairs and drive. I am unable to have a sex life. Is it normal to do both operations at the same time? Can you explain any possible cause for pain?
raw_output:

I am now in more pain than I was before the operation. My testicle thorns with pain constantly and I have stabbing pain on hernia side. It feels like someone is sticking a bottle in me. I am struggling to walk very far, climb stairs and drive. I am unable to have a sex life. Is it normal to do both operations at the same time? Can you explain any possible cause for pain?

### Response:It is not uncommon to experience pain after surgery, especially when undergoing multiple procedures at the same time. The pain you are experiencing could be due to several factors.

1. Inguinal Hernia: A hernia occurs when an organ pushes through a weak spot in the surrounding muscle or tissue. After the repair surgery, it is normal to have some discomfort or swelling around the incision site. This can cause pain and discomfort.

2. Hydrocele: A hydrocele is a collection of fluid around the testicle. During the hydrocele surgery, a small incision may have been made to drain the fluid. If there is any residual fluid or inflammation, it can lead to pain and discomfort.

3. Adhesions: After surgery, scar tissue (adhesions) may form between different organs or tissues. These adhesions can cause pain and discomfort, especially during activities such as walking or sexual intercourse.

4. Infection: Although rare, there is a possibility of developing an infection at the surgical site. This can cause persistent pain and other symptoms such as fever or redness.

5. Nerve Irritation: Surgical procedures near the groin area can potentially irritate nearby nerves, leading to ongoing pain.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,What is colon cleansing? Colon hydrotherapy has been advised, and how effective is the procedure? I have chronic constipation.

### Response:Colon cleansing or colon hydrotherapy is a procedure that involves the use of water to cleanse the colon (large intestine). It is done through the insertion of a flexible tube with a water jet attached to it into the rectum and colon. The water is used to flush out waste material from the colon.

The effectiveness of colon hydrotherapy in treating chronic constipation can vary. Some people may experience relief from their symptoms after the procedure, while others may not. The success of colon hydrotherapy depends on various factors such as the underlying cause of the constipation, the individual's overall health, and their adherence to any recommended follow-up treatments.

It is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific condition and determine if colon hydrotherapy is an appropriate treatment option for you. They will be able to provide more personalized information based on your medical history and current symptoms.

input: Hello doctor,My mom is 56 years old. She is a patient of hypertension, diabetes, and mild nephropathy. BP 140/80, pulse 96/ min, creatinine 1.3, fasting sugar 125, postprandial 157. From a few months, my mother is suffering from chest pain. The doctor told it is chronic stable angina. All other tests are done like Na, K, hemoglobin, urea, and uric acid. The reports are quite fine. Our family doctor suggests me to take angiography. So, what should I do now? Please suggest. She is taking the following medicines: Aciloc RD, Glimmy 2, Nexovas, Telmikaa40, Febugood 40, Lipikind 10 and Glypten 20.
raw_output:

### Input:
Hello doctor,My mom is 56 years old. She is a patient of hypertension, diabetes, and mild nephropathy. BP 140/80, pulse 96/ min, creatinine 1.3, fasting sugar 125, postprandial 157. From a few months, my mother is suffering from chest pain. The doctor told it is chronic stable angina. All other tests are done like Na, K, hemoglobin, urea, and uric acid. The reports are quite fine. Our family doctor suggests me to take angiography. So, what should I do now? Please suggest. She is taking the following medicines: Aciloc RD, Glimmy 2, Nexovas, Telmikaa40, Febugood 40, Lipikind 10 and Glypten 20.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems like your mother has several medical conditions including hypertension, diabetes, and mild nephropathy. The current blood pressure reading is 140/80, pulse rate is 96 beats per minute, and creatinine level is 1.3. The fasting and postprandial blood sugar levels are also elevated at 125 and 157 respectively.

The chest pain your mother is experiencing is being attributed to chronic stable angina. All other tests such as Na, K, hemoglobin, urea, and uric acid are within normal limits. The family doctor suggests angiography as the next step.

Considering these findings, I would recommend discussing the possibility of coronary artery disease (CAD) with your mother's doctor. CAD occurs when there is a buildup of plaque in the arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle. This can lead to chest pain or angina, as well as potentially more serious complications like heart attacks.

Angiography is a diagnostic procedure that allows visualization of the blood vessels in the heart. It involves injecting a contrast dye into the arteries and taking X-ray images to identify any blockages or narrowing in the coronary arteries.

input: Hello doctor,Me and my partner had unprotected sex, and she took I-pill within 72 hours (but after 24 hours), and now after 8 to 9 days of taking the pill, she is having mild cramps similar to period and also mild bleeding (just a few spots), but the discharge is brownish in color, and this is the third day with cramps, although the bleeding is very less. Is it side effect of the pill or is it implantation bleeding? And when can she expect her normal periods?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is possible that your partner is experiencing side effects of the I-pill or implantation bleeding. The I-pill is a type of emergency contraception that works by preventing fertilization of the egg.

Side effects of the I-pill can include cramps, changes in vaginal discharge, and light bleeding. Implantation bleeding occurs when the fertilized egg implants into the uterus, which typically happens around 6 to 12 days after conception.

However, it is important to note that these symptoms can also be indicative of other conditions. To determine whether it is a side effect of the I-pill or implantation bleeding, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your partner's specific situation and provide an accurate diagnosis.

Regarding when her normal periods can be expected, it can vary from person to person. Typically, the first period after starting the I-pill may be delayed or lighter in intensity due to the hormonal changes caused by the medication. However, once her menstrual cycle returns to normal, it should follow its regular pattern.

I recommend advising your partner to schedule an appointment with a healthcare provider to discuss her symptoms and any concerns she may have. They will be able to provide a more accurate diagn

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I do a couple of sports to have some hip flexibility. I am pretty flexible, and I can do right and left splits. But when doing the center split, I get a stopping pain in my outer hip with no stretch in my inner thigh. If I rotate my knees back and hips forward, I can do more stretch, but there is also a slight stop. What is this and can it be worked? Will stretching help to release that stopping pain or am I anatomically incapable of doing a middle split? There is pain only when I am doing a center split. How to fix it? I do a lot of kicking, and I do not want to injure myself.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I do a couple of sports to have some hip flexibility. I am pretty flexible, and I can do right and left splits. But when doing the center split, I get a stopping pain in my outer hip with no stretch in my inner thigh. If I rotate my knees back and hips forward, I can do more stretch, but there is also a slight stop. What is this and can it be worked? Will stretching help to release that stopping pain or am I anatomically incapable of doing a middle split? There is pain only when I am doing a center split. How to fix it? I do a lot of kicking, and I do not want to injure myself.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing a condition called iliopsoas tightness. The iliopsoas muscle is located at the front of your thigh and connects your hip and knee joints. When this muscle becomes tight, it can restrict movement and cause pain, especially during activities that require flexibility such as splits.

To address this issue, I would recommend incorporating regular stretching exercises into your routine. Specifically, focus on stretching the iliopsoas muscle itself. One effective technique is called the figure-four stretch. Here's how you can do it:

1. Stand facing a wall with your hands flat against it, about shoulder-width apart.
2. Step one foot back so that you are in a split-stance position, with your front knee nearly touching the wall.
3. Keeping your hands on the wall, lean forward from the hips until you feel a stretch in the front of your thigh.
4. Hold this position for 30 seconds to a minute, then relax and repeat with the other leg.

Remember to start with gentle stretching and gradually increase the intensity as your muscles become more flexible. It is also important to maintain proper form and avoid forcing the stretch beyond your comfort level.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to consult with a physical therapist or sports

input: Hello doctor,I have complicated migraines, simple partial seizures and are controlled by Lamictal. I have a long time pain from sound intake and it has worsened into my face. Other sensory triggers the pain. It has become just way too much to handle. I sought advice from friends and groups and nurses, that have trigeminal neuralgia and they suggest Carbamazepine.I learned it lowers Lamictal. I contacted pharmacy that said many will test blood serum of Lamictal and then add Carbamazepine and adjust Lamictal to therapeutic levels.My doctor is a bit concerned. She is not a pain doctor or neurologist. I am waiting to see one. But my condition makes it hard to travel in a car. My doctor asked I seek advice. Do you agree that checking the serum and adjusting is fine to do, in order to take Carbamazepine?The second option is Oxcarbazepine. In your experience is it a good pain drug for TN and does it mess up Lamictal? I found a study that said it did not.I was thinking I could start it now while I wait on Lamictal levels. And see if it helps. Just really struggling. Pain cream not helping much in certain places. My old neurologist wanted me to lower Glutamate as much as I could and suggested Namenda at one point. I know many people are on two and three drugs. I hope to try injections for the pain soon. Do you have any suggestions?

Permanent retainers are sometimes recommended in certain cases to provide long-term stability and prevent further shifting of the teeth. I would recommend scheduling an appointment with your orthodontist to discuss your concerns and explore the possibility of a permanent retainer. They will be able to assess your specific situation and provide you with appropriate guidance.

input: Hi doctor,My daughter has skin lesions that started last year. They are on one side of the body. We were confused as is it vitiligo or not and also as we are applying strong creams for a 6-year-old girl. Any long-term issues?We want to have a second opinion. I live in a city where it is very difficult to get skin specialist appointments. They give for every three to six months. Could you please help us in diagnosing the skin patches and treatment? I can send in the photos. I uploaded the photos:They all are on one side of the body (right side).On the hand, it started four months ago with a small white patch and gradually increased to the size and then we are seeing some repigmentation slowly very slowly to normal skin color.On the chest also, it started around the same time this year and not increased and stable.On the neck, it started early last month and it is not that whitish (like little less brownish).As said, the doctors diagnosed differently (postinflammatory hypopigmentation, tinea versicolor and finally vitiligo) so far and we are confused. Could you please look into this and help us?In all these spots, we applied Corticosteroid last year for eczema (hand, neck, chest and back) at the same spots where the white patches started and then grown big now. The only spot where we have not applied Corticosteroid but observed white patch is on the eye. We started seeing a white patch on the right eye as well from the last three weeks.

Another possibility is a muscle or tendon strain. Injury to the muscles or tendons in the forearm can result in swelling and the formation of a hard lump. Again, since you mentioned that there is no pain with movement, this could also be a possibility.

It is important to note that without a physical examination, it is challenging to determine the exact cause of the lump. input: Hello doctor,I see a black dot that has not gone away since yesterday does not move when I rub my eye or blink. It is more significant than floaters I usually see. It seems to move when I jiggle my eye a lot and moves slowly down after I shake my eye.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hello doctor,I see a black dot that has not gone away since yesterday does not move when I rub my eye or blink. It is more significant than floaters I usually see. It seems to move when I jiggle my eye a lot and moves slowly down after I shake my eye.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that they are experiencing a condition called posterior vitreous detachment (PVD). PVD occurs when the gel-like vitreous inside the eye becomes liquefied and pulls away from the retina. This can cause floaters, which are small specks or shapes that seem to float in your field of vision. The presence of a black dot that does not move with eye movement and blinking, as well as slow movement after eye shaking, is consistent with PVD. It is important to note that while PVD is typically a harmless condition, it may be associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which can lead to vision loss in severe cases. Therefore, it is recommended to have a comprehensive eye examination by an ophthalmologist to further evaluate the patient's symptoms and rule out any underlying eye conditions.

Around 9-12 months ago, I started to suffer from anal itching.It is rather intense at night, after passing stools and during/after having intercourse or anal masturbation.I also have few lumps on my anal ring that seem to grow outside of my anal opening as an extended piece of flesh.They are very sensitive but they are odd and it really troubles me.I fear that my problem started as a result of anal masturbation and anal sex.I feel very ashamed to say this. I was using anal toys and hand and I am afraid that during these years I myself  have created problems to my health and I do not know how to fix it.I do not have constipation and my stool is normal.I pass motion once a day and I have no abdominal pain while passing stools.Sometimes when I have anal sex I start bleeding from my rectum for a few seconds and then it stops.It does not bleed when I pass stools or any other time.I have not attained menopause even though my period seems to be every 6-7 weeks these days.I would appreciate if you can help me understand how to treat this issue and what should I do (i.e, special diet, special creams, instructions on how to clean the area etc.)Help me please, I am looking for a very discreet way to handle my situation since I am too concerned about talking with my spouse.

input: Hello doctor,I had unprotected sex on my infertile day, but I was quite scared, so I took post-pill a week later I had another unprotected sex this time in my fertile days but did not receive the post-pill immediately next day I saw a slight spotting which prompted me into taking the emergency pill. Now a week later, I have been bleeding for two days. I hope this is not a sign of pregnancy. Please help me understand it better.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had unprotected sex on my infertile day, but I was quite scared, so I took post-pill a week later I had another unprotected sex this time in my fertile days but did not receive the post-pill immediately next day I saw a slight spotting which prompted me into taking the emergency pill. Now a week later, I have been bleeding for two days. I hope this is not a sign of pregnancy. Please help me understand it better.

### Response:Based on the information you provided, it is possible that you are experiencing a side effect of the emergency contraceptive pill. The emergency contraceptive pill works by inhibiting ovulation and preventing fertilization. However, it does not cause an abortion or affect an existing pregnancy.

The bleeding you mentioned could be related to the hormonal changes caused by the emergency contraceptive pill. It is common to experience some spotting or light bleeding after taking the pill. This usually resolves within a few days or weeks.

Since you mentioned that you are not experiencing any other symptoms of pregnancy, such as abdominal pain or missed periods, it is unlikely that the bleeding is a sign of pregnancy. However, it is always recommended to confirm with a pregnancy test if you are concerned about pregnancy.

If the bleeding continues or worsens, it is important to seek medical advice from a healthcare provider. They can further evaluate your symptoms and provide appropriate guidance.

input: Hello doctor,Can an echocardiogram and ECG diagnose restrictive cardiomyopathy because I have had like three of them but I am still confused? All I have is just some premature ventricular contractions.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,Can an echocardiogram and ECG diagnose restrictive cardiomyopathy because I have had like three of them but I am still confused? All I have is just some premature ventricular contractions.

### Response:Hello, I am sorry to hear that you are confused about your diagnosis. Echocardiogram and ECG can be useful tools in diagnosing various heart conditions, including restrictive cardiomyopathy. However, it is important to note that these tests alone may not provide a definitive diagnosis of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is a type of heart muscle disease characterized by stiffening of the heart muscle, which affects its ability to relax and fill with blood properly. Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) can also occur in this condition.

To accurately diagnose restrictive cardiomyopathy, additional information and evaluation are needed. This may include a comprehensive medical history, physical examination, other diagnostic tests such as cardiac MRI or CT scan, and assessment of the heart's function through stress tests or Holter monitoring.

It is recommended that you consult with a cardiologist who can review your previous test results, assess your symptoms, and order any necessary additional tests to help clarify the diagnosis. They will be able to provide you with a more accurate understanding of your condition and guide you towards appropriate treatment options.

input: Hello doctor,From the past five days, I am sending my 21 month old son to a daycare. For the first three days, they allowed me inside the campus. Since I was close by, he was playing well. But, from the last two days, they are not allowing me inside and hence he is crying a lot. Today he was a bit fine but, not actually enjoying. Will it affect my child\s health? Will it create any psychological problem in him? I have heard that the cortisol hormone levels will be changed. Is that true? My in-laws are not staying with us. So, I have to either send him to the day care or I will have to send him to my in-laws\. Which is the best option?

2. Psychological problem: Separation anxiety is a common developmental milestone in children and can manifest as tears or clinginess when leaving a familiar person or place. However, with time and consistent care, most children learn to adjust and develop healthy coping mechanisms.

3. Changes in cortisol hormone levels: Cortisol is a hormone associated with stress, and its levels can fluctuate depending on various factors, including anxiety and emotional distress. While it is true that children may experience increased cortisol levels during times of stress or transition, it is important to note that excessive or prolonged elevation of cortisol levels can be indicative of underlying issues.

4. Best option: The best option for your child's well-being would depend on several factors, such as the quality and safety of the daycare facility, your work schedule, and your in-laws' ability

Before recommending a testicular biopsy, it would be advisable to further investigate the cause of your azoospermia. Here are a few additional tests that could be considered:

1. Hormone level tests: These can help determine if there are any hormonal imbalances that may be contributing to the issue.
2. Sperm DNA fragmentation test: This test assesses the integrity of the sperm DNA, which can provide valuable information about the potential for fertilization.
3. Anti-sperm antibody test: This test looks for the presence of antibodies that may be attacking and damaging the sperm.
4. Genetic testing: It can identify any genetic abnormalities that may contribute to infertility.

I understand your concern regarding the testicular biopsy, but

input: Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems that your sister has a condition called Turner syndrome, which is characterized by the absence or structural abnormalities of one of her X chromosomes. The karyotype result of 46, XY (20), 20 cells indicates that there are only 20 chromosomes present in her cells instead of the usual 46.

Turner syndrome can cause various physical and hormonal changes, including delayed or absent menstruation. It is important to note that not all individuals with Turner syndrome will have difficulty conceiving, as it can vary from person to person. However, it is recommended that your sister consult with a reproductive specialist who can assess her specific situation and provide guidance on fertility options.

In terms of treatment, there are several possibilities depending on the severity of her condition and her individual needs. These may include hormone replacement therapy to regulate her menstrual cycle, management of any associated health issues such as heart defects or kidney problems, and fertility interventions if desired.

It is essential for your sister to seek medical attention from a healthcare professional specializing in Turner syndrome to receive a comprehensive evaluation and personalized treatment plan. They will be able to provide more accurate information regarding her fertility potential and guide her through any necessary interventions.

input: Hi doctor,I have low energy for a few days now. I have done a blood test, and I have a ferritin level of 10 ng/mL. After taking supplements, my ferritin got increased to 16 ng/mL. But, still, I suffer from weakness. My doctor advised me to have an iron infusion to raise my levels. I still have low energy, and it is affecting my daily life. Can I take an infusion now? Can it help me? Please suggest.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I have low energy for a few days now. I have done a blood test, and I have a ferritin level of 10 ng/mL. After taking supplements, my ferritin got increased to 16 ng/mL. But, still, I suffer from weakness. My doctor advised me to have an iron infusion to raise my levels. I still have low energy, and it is affecting my daily life. Can I take an infusion now? Can it help me? Please suggest.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you have iron deficiency anemia. Iron infusion is a common treatment for severe cases of iron deficiency anemia. It involves administering a concentrated dose of iron directly into your bloodstream.

Having a ferritin level of 10 ng/mL indicates a low iron stores in your body. The increase in ferritin level to 16 ng/mL after supplementation suggests that the supplements were effective in replenishing your iron stores. However, if you still have low energy despite this increase, it indicates that your body's iron requirement may be higher than what can be achieved through oral supplements alone.

In such cases, an iron infusion can provide a rapid and significant increase in iron levels, which may help alleviate symptoms such as fatigue and weakness. It is important to consult with your doctor before proceeding with an iron infusion. They will assess your overall health, evaluate the severity of your anemia, and determine if an iron infusion is appropriate for you.

Please note that this recommendation is based on the information provided and does not substitute for professional medical advice. It is essential to consult with your healthcare provider to discuss your specific situation and determine the best course of action.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I got my cavity filled two days back. Now, it hurts when I drink cold stuff. Is there anything I can do?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I got my cavity filled two days back. Now, it hurts when I drink cold stuff. Is there anything I can do?

### Response:Hello, I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing pain after getting your cavity filled. It is common for teeth to be sensitive to hot or cold food and drinks for a few days after a filling. Here are a few suggestions that may help alleviate the discomfort:

1. Rinse your mouth with warm saltwater: This can help reduce inflammation and promote healing.
2. Avoid consuming hot or cold foods and drinks: Give your teeth some time to adjust before exposing them to extreme temperatures.
3. Gradually introduce cold substances: Start by drinking warm beverages and then gradually move towards consuming cold ones. This allows your teeth to adapt to the temperature change.
4. Use a soft-bristle toothbrush: Brushing your teeth gently can help prevent further irritation.
5. Take over-the-counter pain relievers: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Follow the recommended dosage instructions.

If the pain persists or worsens after a few days, it would be advisable to contact your dentist for further evaluation and guidance. They may suggest additional measures or even a follow-up appointment if needed.

PSA is a protein produced by the cells of the prostate gland, and its levels can fluctuate naturally. However, an increase in PSA levels can also be indicative of prostate-related conditions, such as prostatitis or prostate cancer.

Given that you are currently on testosterone replacement therapy, it is important to consider the potential impact of this treatment on your PSA levels. Testosterone therapy has been associated with an increase in PSA levels, which may lead to false-positive results for prostate cancer.

I would recommend discussing these findings with your healthcare provider who can further evaluate your specific situation and determine the appropriate course of action. They may choose to repeat the PSA test to confirm the results and consider additional tests, such as a digital rectal exam (DRE) or a prostate biopsy if necessary.

It is important not to panic, but rather approach this situation cautiously and seek medical advice to ensure appropriate management.

The symptoms she is experiencing, such as touching her tongue and feeling a sensation on her tongue, can be associated with the presence of fungus. The redness at the tip of her tongue may also be a result of irritation caused by the fungus.

It is important to address the issue of oral thrush as it can sometimes lead to discomfort and difficulty in eating, speaking, or swallowing. Prompt medical attention will help alleviate her symptoms and prevent any complications.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 34 year old male. I had anxiety issues since childhood. I have been jumping from one idea to another for a long time but it has been three years I have an issue with frequent urination. It started in a bad time for me when I was obsessing that I have HIV. No burning, just slight urethra burning. I went to a urologist. He told me nothing was wrong, maybe an overactive bladder. I go to the toilet every two hours or three. I never knew what was wrong, but I started to obsess over it and it got worse to a place that my mind is in urination 24/7. I almost gave up until I went on a vacation and during that vacation, I forgot about it totally. The frequency was gone and even the burning urethra. Also, I had to remove my wisdom teeth and when I did, I was so occupied thinking about it that I forgot about urination and I noticed that I do not use the bathroom like I used to. But, I got back obsessing about it again and it got to a point that I urinate a lot of high volumes every hour. It comes suddenly and goes on its own. I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. Can anxiety cause polyuria like this clear urine when I am stressed?

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?

### Response:The regular contraceptive pill and the emergency contraceptive pill, also known as the "morning-after pill," are both forms of birth control. However, they have different mechanisms of action and are used for different situations.

The regular contraceptive pill is a hormonal medication that is taken regularly to prevent pregnancy. It works by inhibiting ovulation (the release of an egg from the ovaries) and thickening the cervical mucus to block sperm from reaching the egg. This type of pill needs to be taken consistently every day to be effective.

On the other hand, the emergency contraceptive pill, also known as the I-pill, is used post-unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. It contains higher doses of hormones than the regular pill and works by delaying or inhibiting ovulation. The I-pill can be taken within 72 hours (three days) after unprotected sex to reduce the risk of pregnancy.

In summary, the regular contraceptive pill is taken regularly to prevent pregnancy, while the emergency contraceptive pill is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy.

input: Hi,My age is 29 years. Yesterday I drank ice cold water in the afternoon. Since today morning I am feeling pain in the throat, body pain and laziness. Please suggest medicine for the same.

### Input:
Hi,My age is 29 years. Yesterday I drank ice cold water in the afternoon. Since today morning I am feeling pain in the throat, body pain and laziness. Please suggest medicine for the same.

### Response:Based on your symptoms of pain in the throat, body pain, and laziness after drinking ice cold water, it is possible that you are experiencing a reaction called "brain freeze." This occurs when you consume something very cold, causing temporary numbness or pain in the mouth and sometimes the throat.

To alleviate the discomfort, you can try the following remedies:
1. Drinking warm liquids such as herbal tea or warm water.
2. Chewing on a piece of ginger.
3. Sucking on a popsicle or licking an ice cream cone to reduce the sensation of coldness in your mouth.
4. Avoiding extremely cold foods and drinks for a while.

If your symptoms persist or worsen, it would be best to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation and appropriate treatment.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it seems like you are experiencing symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). GAD is a chronic condition characterized by excessive and uncontrollable worry or fear about various aspects of life.

Zoloft (sertraline) is an antidepressant medication that belongs to the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) class. It is commonly used to treat anxiety disorders, including GAD. Zoloft works by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain, which can help regulate mood and reduce anxiety.

While Zoloft may be effective in managing symptoms of GAD, it may take some time for the medication to take full effect. It is important to continue taking the medication as prescribed by your doctor and follow up with them regularly to monitor your progress.

It's worth mentioning that Zoloft may not be suitable for everyone, and individual responses to medication can vary. If you are experiencing persistent negative thoughts or self-harm ideation, it is important to seek immediate professional help from a mental health specialist. They will be able to provide a thorough assessment and recommend appropriate treatment options based on your specific needs.

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.

5. Sun protection: Protect your skin from sun exposure by using a broad-spectrum sun

input: Hello doctor,I just want to consult about my skin condition that happens annually. Every year, my hands has this condition where it will itch and form rashes with liquid inside then skin itself. Most of the time, it starts on December then end on February, however it differs every year. This year it started on March and up to now. I experience this every year, as in yearly so I assumed it is normal. It is not hereditary, I assume, because none of my family members is experiencing it other than me.My mother told me that maybe it is because of cold weather which I agreed. It is there for the past 11 years. I have never consulted any professionals about it since it does not look severe. However, I am curious what is this condition called.

They will be able to provide you with specific recommendations tailored to your individual needs and help you manage this condition effectively.

input: Hello doctor,I am 47 today. I went to my primary doctor three years ago with low libido and poor quality erections. Blood work came back as total testosterone 381 and A1c 6.9. Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is important to consider the patient's symptoms and medical history. The patient has a history of low libido and poor quality erections, which are common symptoms of low testosterone levels.

The initial blood work showed a total testosterone level of 381 ng/dL, which is considered high. However, the symptoms did not improve with this elevated testosterone level. This suggests that the patient may have developed resistance to testosterone.

The subsequent blood work revealed a testosterone level of 900 ng/dL, which is considered very high. Despite this high level, the patient still experienced symptoms, indicating that the testosterone resistance is likely contributing to the persistence of symptoms.

The doctor's recommendation of testosterone replacement therapy (TRT) along with Clomid seems appropriate in this case. TRT can help address the low testosterone levels and improve the symptoms associated with it. Clomid can further support testosterone levels and enhance libido.

It is important to note that TRT is not without potential side effects. Regular monitoring of hormone levels and side effects is necessary during treatment.

In terms of the second opinion, seeking input from an endocrinologist would be beneficial. An endocrinologist specializes in hormonal disorders

input: Hello doctor,My baby is 3.5 months old. In my house, they are saying to give urai marundhu is it safe to give? As my daughter is licking her fingers, my mom wants to keep castor oil or neem oil, is it safe to keep it on her finger?
raw_output:

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My baby is 3.5 months old. In my house, they are saying to give urai marundhu is it safe to give? As my daughter is licking her fingers, my mom wants to keep castor oil or neem oil, is it safe to keep it on her finger?

### Response:Hello! I am a medical expert. Thank you for reaching out with your concerns about your baby.

Regarding the question of whether it is safe to give urai marundhu (castor oil) or neem oil to your 3.5-month-old baby, I would advise against it. Both castor oil and neem oil are not recommended for infants under the age of 6 months. These oils can be potentially harmful if ingested in large amounts and may cause constipation, vomiting, diarrhea, or other gastrointestinal issues. It is generally not recommended to keep these oils on the fingers of an infant either.

Instead, I would recommend using gentle, unscented baby soap and warm water to clean your baby's hands and fingers regularly. If you have any specific concerns or questions about your baby's health, it is always best to consult with your pediatrician for personalized advice.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,One year back, while sitting on a chair in office I felt as if my back got stuck and was unable to move. I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. I am only 27 years old and unable to do simple tasks like sitting for five minutes. Please help me, what could be the possible reason for all this.I had some back pain three years ago. My lifestyle is also not good. I do not used to any exercise or walk earlier, only sitting on a chair in front of a computer for 10-11 hours. I have also gained weight of 15 kg in 10 months. Right now, I am taking only Vitamin D3 supplement. I am attaching all my reports for your reference.

Angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the fluid inside the eye cannot properly drain due to a blockage in the drainage angle of the eye. This can lead to increased pressure in the eye, which can cause damage to the optic nerve and result in vision loss.

The symptoms you described, including a decreased vision in the right eye followed by worsening vision in the left eye, are consistent with the progression of angle-closure glaucoma. The normal fundus and clinical examinations suggest that there is no active inflammation or other acute issues affecting the eyes at the present time.

The OCT findings of nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning further support the diagnosis of angle-closure glaucoma. These imaging tests can detect changes in the optic nerve and retinal nerve fiber layer, which are commonly seen in this condition.

Given that your symptoms have not improved after three months, it is important to consider the possibility of permanent vision loss if left untreated. It would be advisable to consult with an ophthalmologist or a glaucoma specialist for further evaluation and management options.
