instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you have tried multiple medications for your bipolar 2 disorder, OCD, and social anxiety disorder. It is concerning to hear that none of the medications have been effective for you over a period of 2 1/2 years. This suggests that you may have treatment-resistant depression.

When it comes to treatment-resistant depression, there are a few options that can be considered:

1. Switching medications: You could potentially try switching to a different class of antidepressants or trying a combination of medications. For example, instead of SSRIs or SNRIs, you could try tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) or atypical antidepressants like bupropion.

2. Augmentation therapy: Adding an additional medication to your current regimen may help improve symptoms. This could involve adding a mood stabilizer like lithium or valproate, or adding an antipsychotic medication like aripiprazole or quetiapine.

3. Psychotherapy: In addition to medication, psychotherapy can be beneficial in managing symptoms of depression. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or interpersonal therapy (IPT) can help address underlying issues and provide coping strategies.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 30-year-old woman. I am having OCD since I was 12 years old. I have a strong fear of an event that happened a couple of years ago when a psychiatrist told me that I have a borderline disorder and have no fantasy. I was trying to ask her for years to say me the opposite as a compulsion. She refused to do that, I am not sure if it is because she did not want to change her opinion or it is because she did not want to satisfy my compulsion. My mother was encouraging me to do these kinds of compulsions as she thought it is going to get worse. It was a bad thing as she was validating my fears in this way. I just realized these things now so I started to confront my fears about what the psychiatrist said to me. But I ran into another one which is about what if my mother is right and if I am confronting my fears it is going to get worse. What do you think?

OCD is a distinct mental health condition characterized by recurring intrusive thoughts, images, or sensations (obsessions) that lead to repeated behaviors or mental acts (compulsions). These obsessions and compulsions can significantly impact daily life and cause distress.

Your concern about confronting your fears and potentially making things worse is a common one among individuals with OCD. This fear is often referred to as the "worst-case scenario" or "overvalued idea" obsession. It involves worrying that if you confront your fears, they may come true or worsen your symptoms.

While it is understandable to have concerns about potential consequences, confronting your fears is an essential part of OCD treatment. Gradual exposure and response prevention therapy, often used in cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), can help you gradually face your fears

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.

### Response:Based on the information provided, it is important to understand that a stress echo is a diagnostic test used to evaluate how well your heart functions during physical activity. It helps to assess the blood flow to your heart muscle and identify any abnormalities or blockages in the coronary arteries.

In patients with left bundle branch block (LBBB), both chemical and nuclear stress echos can be used to evaluate the heart's function. The choice of stress echo may depend on factors such as the specific findings of the EKG and the patient's overall clinical presentation.

However, it is true that nuclear stress echos are more sensitive than chemical stress echos in detecting coronary artery disease. Therefore, if there is a suspicion or evidence of significant coronary artery disease, a nuclear stress echo may be recommended.

Given your family history of heart disease, it is important to ensure that your heart is functioning properly and there are no significant blockages in the coronary arteries. In terms of pregnancy risks in women over 40, there are some potential considerations. However, it's important to note that advances in medical care and technology have improved outcomes for older mothers. With proper prenatal care and health management, many women over 40 have successful pregnancies and deliver healthy babies.

If you're experiencing pain in your jaws and the areas around the tooth after filling a cavity, it's important to consult with your dentist as soon as possible. In the meantime, you can try a few things to alleviate the discomfort:

1. Rinse your mouth with warm saltwater: This can help reduce inflammation and ease pain.
2. Take over-the-counter pain relievers: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or acetaminophen can help manage the pain.
3. Apply a cold compress: Placing a cold, damp cloth on the outside of your cheek near the affected area may provide temporary relief.
4. Avoid chewing on the affected side: To prevent further discomfort, try to avoid chewing on the jaw that is causing the pain.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional medical advice. It's best to reach out to your dentist as soon as possible to discuss your symptoms and get proper guidance.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you have described, along with your medical history of hypertension, there are a few possible explanations for the froth in your urine and facial puffiness. One possibility is that you may be experiencing proteinuria, which is the presence of excess protein in the urine. This can be a sign of kidney dysfunction or damage.

To further evaluate your condition, I would recommend checking your urine for protein levels and performing a urine protein creatinine ratio (UPCR) test. The UPCR will help determine how much protein is present in your urine compared to the amount of creatinine. A higher ratio indicates greater proteinuria.

Additionally, it would be beneficial to conduct an ultrasound (USG) abdomen to assess any abnormalities in the kidneys, liver, or other abdominal organs. This can help identify any potential underlying causes for your symptoms.

Based on the results of these tests, your doctor can provide you with a more accurate diagnosis and guide you on appropriate management options. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a comprehensive evaluation and personalized treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,My daughter who is 2.8 years old cried hard before two weeks and developed a hoarse voice the next day. It subsided in about three days. Before a week, I remember her throwing tantrums and crying hard for every small thing and again developed a hoarse voice. I gave warm water and honey, and it has subsided a lot.Sometimes her voice sounds normal, and when she screams or cries, I can still feel her voice is a little hoarse. Is this hoarseness due to crying or could be any other infection? I read that hoarseness could occur due to cancer. I am a paranoid mother who gets scared after reading the stuff. She does not have any cold, cough and eats normally.In spite of her hoarse voice, she is taking ice creams and cold stuff. If the hoarseness is due to any serious medical condition, would she have any accompanying symptoms? My main concern is cancer. What would be the symptoms of laryngeal cancer other than hoarseness? She is a very adamant kid and still screams if things do not go her way. Suggest remedies to get rid of hoarseness. Please remove my anxiety towards cancer.

### Response:Hello,

I understand your concerns as a parent. Hoarseness in children can have various causes, and it is important to rule out any serious medical conditions. In this case, the hoarseness is most likely due to crying and not related to cancer. However, it is always a good idea to get a thorough evaluation by a healthcare professional.

Here are some possible causes of hoarseness in children:

1. Vocal cord irritation: This can occur due to frequent crying, screaming, or yelling.
2. Respiratory infections: Colds, flu, or bronchitis can cause inflammation of the vocal cords.

input: Hello doctor,I urinate a lot, almost 32 times a day. When I urinate and come back, after a while, I can feel some urine passes my urinary tract, and I have to urinate again. Can you prescribe some tablets?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I urinate a lot, almost 32 times a day. When I urinate and come back, after a while, I can feel some urine passes my urinary tract, and I have to urinate again. Can you prescribe some tablets?

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it seems like they are experiencing frequent urination and a sensation of urine passing their urinary tract after each urination. This could be indicative of a condition called urge incontinence or overactive bladder.

Urge incontinence occurs when the bladder muscles contract suddenly and urgently, causing urine to leak out before the person can reach the bathroom. Overactive bladder is another term for this condition.

To manage urge incontinence, there are several treatment options available:

1. Medications: There are several medications that can help relax the bladder muscles and reduce urgency. These include anticholinergic drugs (such as oxybutynin) and beta-3 adrenergic agonists (such as mirabegron).

2. Bladder training: This involves scheduling regular bathroom trips and resisting the urge to urinate outside of those times. It can help strengthen the bladder muscles and reduce the frequency of urination.

3. Pelvic floor exercises: Strengthening the pelvic floor muscles can help improve bladder control. These exercises involve squeezing and releasing the muscles that form the floor of the pelvis.

4

### Response:Hepatitis B can be transmitted through saliva, but it is not very common. The detection of the virus in your body indicates an active infection. The viral load of 1.5 * 10^5 count/mL suggests an early stage of the infection.

While there is no cure for hepatitis B, it is possible to achieve a functional cure. This means that the virus will be suppressed to undetectable levels and you will no longer show symptoms or spread the infection to others.

The duration of treatment to achieve a functional cure can vary depending on various factors such as the individual's immune response and adherence to treatment. In general, it takes about 6-12 months of antiviral therapy to achieve sustained virological response (SVR). However, it is important to continue taking medication as prescribed by your doctor even after achieving SVR, as relapses can occur if treatment is stopped prematurely.

It is recommended that you consult with a healthcare professional who specializes in treating hepatitis B to discuss your specific situation and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Hello doctor,I want to know about piles. For the past two days, I am having little bit pain in the anus. I want to know if it is piles or not.

### Response:Hello,

I'm sorry to hear about your symptoms. In order to determine if you have piles or not, it is important to gather more information. Piles, also known as hemorrhoids, are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus. They can cause pain, itching, and bleeding during bowel movements.

To confirm whether you have piles, I would recommend the following:

1. Physical examination: A doctor will typically perform a physical examination of your anus and rectum to check for any visible signs of piles, such as swollen blood vessels or skin tags.

2. Anorectal manometry: This test measures the pressure and sensitivity of the muscles in the anus and rectum. It can help determine if there are any abnormalities that could contribute to your symptoms.

3. Proctoscopy: This is a procedure where a thin, flexible tube with a camera (proctoscope) is inserted into the rectum to examine the lining of the rectum and detect any abnormalities, including piles.

Based on the results of these examinations, your doctor will be able to provide a definitive diagnosis and recommend appropriate treatment options.

I would advise you to consult with a healthcare professional who can conduct a thorough examination and provide personalized advice

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am writing for my daughter, staying away from us, with her husband. She is 30 years, 5 feet 1 inch and 63 kg, working in the IT sector. She is married for the last three years and seriously trying for conception from a year. She missed her period once in the beginning of this year. During her obstetrics consultation, beta hCG was done. It was repeated after two days. A transvaginal ultrasound scan was done and repeated after 10 days. The end result was diagnosed as a blighted ovum. So, it was evacuated by D and C.Our daughter is of normal build and nutrition. Her menstrual history was normal since the beginning in terms of cycle, duration, and flow. But, one month after D and C, she did not have her period. On the doctor's advice, she took some medicines and bleeding occurred. She was known hypothyroid. So, she was taking Thyroxin 50 or 75 to keep the TSH near about 2.5 Uiu/ml. Her Hb % and sugar are within the normal range.Again, she tried to conceive since three months ago along with Aspirin and folic acid. She missed her period last month. Her beta hCG was 9.20 mIu/ mL. It was repeated after two days. It came down to 1 Miu/ml suggestive of \chemical pregnancy\. This time, after a few days, a spontaneous jelly-like bleeding occurred for two days. I would like to add that her husband requires to take Penegra 50 mg tab before a performance. Our daughter is immunized with triple antigen, polio, MMR, chickenpox and hepatitis B vaccine in childhood. The transvaginal scan (done at a later phase of the first conception) showed normal anatomical and physiological pattern of the ovary and uterus to me at least (report attached).Two consecutive miscarriages brought great disappointment to all. Presently, the doctor told her to take Aspirin 150 mg, folic acid, and Vitamin B12 combination tablet and to try for pregnancy again. I want your valuable opinion regarding subsequent management or the right line of treatment and suggestions or tests (if any) to get a successful pregnancy and healthy baby.
